built with pdoc

icepool

Package for computing dice and card probabilities.

See this JupyterLite distribution for examples.

Visit the project page.

General conventions:

  • Instances are immutable (apart from internal caching). Anything that looks like it mutates an instance actually returns a separate instance with the change.
  • Unless explictly specified otherwise, all sorting is in ascending order.
  • The words "min" and "max" refer to outcomes, and the words "low" and "high" refer to dice in a pool.
 1"""Package for computing dice and card probabilities.
 2
 3See [this JupyterLite distribution](https://highdiceroller.github.io/icepool/notebooks/lab/index.html)
 4for examples.

 6[Visit the project page.](https://github.com/HighDiceRoller/icepool)

11    like it mutates an instance actually returns a separate instance with the
12    change.
13* Unless explictly specified otherwise, all sorting is in ascending order.
14* The words "min" and "max" refer to outcomes, and the words "low" and "high"
15refer to dice in a pool.

@cache
def standard(num_sides: int, /) -> icepool.Die: 
15@cache
16def standard(num_sides: int, /) -> 'icepool.Die':
17    """A standard die.
18
19    Specifically, the outcomes are `int`s from `1` to `num_sides` inclusive,
20    with weight 1 each.
21
22    Don't confuse this with `icepool.Die()`:
23
24    * `icepool.Die(6)`: A die that always rolls the integer 6.
25    * `icepool.d(6)`: A d6.
26    """
27    if not isinstance(num_sides, int):
28        raise TypeError('Argument to standard() must be an int.')
29    elif num_sides < 1:
30        raise ValueError('Standard die must have at least one side.')
31    return icepool.Die(range(1, num_sides + 1))

53def bernoulli(n: int, d: int) -> 'icepool.Die':
54    """A die that rolls `True` with chance `n / d`, and `False` otherwise. """
55    return icepool.Die({False: d - n, True: n})

class Die: 
  22class Die():
  23    """An immutable mapping of outcomes to nonnegative `int` weights.
  24
  25    Dice are immutable. Methods do not modify the die in-place;
  26    rather they return a die representing the result.
  27
  28    It *is* (mostly) well-defined to have a die with zero-weight outcomes,
  29    even though this is not a proper probability distribution.
  30    These can be useful in a few cases, such as:
  31
  32    * `Pool` and `EvalPool` will iterate through zero-weight outcomes
  33        with 0 `count`, rather than `None` or skipping that outcome.
  34    * `icepool.align()` and the like are convenient for making dice share the
  35        same set of outcomes.
  36
  37    However, zero-weight outcomes have a computational cost like any other
  38    outcome. Unless you have a specific use case in mind, it's best to leave
  39    them out.
  40
  41    Most operators and methods will not introduce zero-weight outcomes if their
  42    arguments do not have any.
  43
  44    It's also possible to have "empty" dice with no outcomes at all,
  45    though these have little use other than being sentinel values.
  46    """
  47
  48    _data: Counts
  49
  50    def __new__(cls,
  51                outcomes: Mapping[Any, int] | Sequence,
  52                times: Sequence[int] | int = 1,
  53                denominator_method: str = 'lcm') -> 'Die':
  54        """Constructor for a die.
  55
  56        Don't confuse this with `d()`:
  57
  58        * `Die([6])`: A die that always rolls the `int` 6.
  59        * `d(6)`: A d6.
  60
  61        Also, don't confuse this with `Pool()`:
  62
  63        * `Die([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6])`: A d6.
  64        * `Pool([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6])`: A pool of six dice that always rolls one
  65            of each number.
  66
  67        Here are some different ways of constructing a d6:
  68
  69        * Just import it: `from icepool import d6`
  70        * Use the `d()` function: `icepool.d(6)`
  71        * Use a d6 that you already have: `Die(d6)`
  72        * Mix a d3 and a d3+3: `Die(d3, d3+3)`
  73        * Use a dict: `Die({1:1, 2:1, 3:1, 4:1, 5:1, 6:1})`
  74        * Give the faces as args: `Die(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6)`
  75
  76        All weights must be non-negative, though they can be zero.
  77
  78        Args:
  79            outcomes: The outcomes of the die. This can be one of the following:
  80                * A dict mapping outcomes to weights.
  81                * A sequence of outcomes. Each element will have the same total
  82                    weight.
  83
  84                Each outcome may be one of the following:
  85                * A `Die`. The outcomes of the die will be "flattened" into the
  86                    result; a `Die` will never contain a `Die` as an outcome.
  87                * A dict-like that maps outcomes to weights.
  88                    The outcomes of the dict-like will be "flattened" into the
  89                    result. This option will be taken in preference to treating
  90                    the dict-like itself as an outcome even if the dict-like
  91                    itself is hashable and totally orderable.
  92                * A tuple of outcomes. Operators on dice with tuple outcomes
  93                    are performed element-wise. See `Die.unary_op` and
  94                    `Die.binary_op` for details.
  95
  96                    Any tuple elements that are dice or dicts will expand the
  97                    tuple according to their independent joint distribution.
  98                    For example, `(d6, d6)` will expand to 36 ordered tuples
  99                    with weight 1 each. Use this carefully since it may create a
 100                    large number of outcomes.
 101                * `icepool.Reroll`, which will drop itself
 102                    and the corresponding element of `times` from consideration.
 103                    If inside a tuple, the tuple will be dropped.
 104                * Anything else, including non-tuple sequences, will be treated
 105                    as a single outcome. Each outcome must be hashable, and the
 106                    set of outcomes must be totally orderable (after expansion).
 107                    The same outcome can appear multiple times, in which case
 108                    the corresponding weights will be accumulated.
 109            times: Multiplies the weight of each element of `outcomes`.
 110                `times` can either be a sequence of the same length as
 111                `outcomes` or a single `int` to apply to all elements of
 112                `outcomes`.
 113            denominator_method: How to determine the denominator of the result
 114                if the arguments themselves contain weights. This is also used
 115                for dict-like arguments. From greatest to least:
 116                * 'prod': Product of the individual argument denominators, times
 117                    the total of `weights`. This is like rolling all of the
 118                    possible dice, and then selecting a result.
 119                * 'lcm' (default): LCM of the individual argument denominators,
 120                    times the total of `weights`. This is like rolling `weights`
 121                    first, then selecting an argument to roll.
 122                * 'lcm_weighted': LCM of the individual (argument denominators
 123                    times corresponding element of `weights`). This is like
 124                    rolling the above, but the specific weight rolled is used
 125                    to help determine the result of the selected argument.
 126                * 'reduce': The final weights are divided by their GCD.
 127        Raises:
 128            `ValueError`: `None` is not a valid outcome for a die.
 129        """
 130        if isinstance(outcomes, Die):
 131            if times == 1:
 132                return outcomes
 133            else:
 134                outcomes = outcomes._data
 135
 136        outcomes, times = icepool.creation_args.itemize(outcomes, times)
 137
 138        if len(outcomes) == 1 and times[0] == 1 and isinstance(
 139                outcomes[0], Die):
 140            return outcomes[0]
 141
 142        self = super(Die, cls).__new__(cls)
 143        self._data = icepool.creation_args.expand_args_for_die(
 144            outcomes, times, denominator_method=denominator_method)
 145        return self
 146
 147    def unary_op(self, op: Callable, *args, **kwargs) -> 'Die':
 148        """Performs the unary operation on the outcomes.
 149
 150        Operations on tuples are performed elementwise recursively. If you need
 151        some other specific behavior, use your own outcome class, or use `sub()`
 152        rather than an operator.
 153
 154        This is used for the standard unary operators
 155        `-, +, abs, ~, round, trunc, floor, ceil`
 156        as well as the additional methods
 157        `zero, bool`.
 158
 159        This is NOT used for the `[]` operator, which is NOT performed
 160        element-wise.
 161
 162        Returns:
 163            A die representing the result.
 164
 165        Raises:
 166            ValueError if tuples are of mismatched length.
 167        """
 168        data: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
 169        for outcome, weight in self.items():
 170            new_outcome = unary_elementwise(outcome, op, *args, **kwargs)
 171            data[new_outcome] += weight
 172        return icepool.Die(data)
 173
 174    def unary_op_non_elementwise(self, op: Callable, *args, **kwargs) -> 'Die':
 175        """As `unary_op()`, but not elementwise.
 176
 177        This is used for the `[]` operator.
 178        """
 179        data: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
 180        for outcome, weight in self.items():
 181            new_outcome = op(outcome, *args, **kwargs)
 182            data[new_outcome] += weight
 183        return icepool.Die(data)
 184
 185    def binary_op(self, other: 'Die', op: Callable, *args, **kwargs) -> 'Die':
 186        """Performs the operation on pairs of outcomes.
 187
 188        Operations on tuples are performed elementwise recursively. If you need
 189        some other specific behavior, use your own outcome class, or use `sub()`
 190        rather than an operator.
 191
 192        By the time this is called, the other operand has already been
 193        converted to a die.
 194
 195        This is used for the standard binary operators
 196        `+, -, *, /, //, %, **, <<, >>, &, |, ^, <, <=, >=, >, ==, !=`,
 197        as well as the additional method `cmp`.
 198        Note that `*` multiplies outcomes directly;
 199        it is not the same as `@`, which rolls the right side multiple times,
 200        or `d()`, which creates a standard die.
 201
 202        `==` and `!=` additionally set the truth value of the die according to
 203        whether the dice themselves are the same or not.
 204
 205        The `@` operator does NOT use this method directly.
 206        It rolls the left die, which must have integer outcomes,
 207        then rolls the right die that many times and sums the outcomes.
 208        Only the sum is performed element-wise.
 209
 210        Returns:
 211            A die representing the result.
 212
 213        Raises:
 214            `ValueError` if tuples are of mismatched length within one of the
 215                dice or between the dice.
 216        """
 217        data: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
 218        for (outcome_self, weight_self), (outcome_other,
 219                                          weight_other) in itertools.product(
 220                                              self.items(), other.items()):
 221            new_outcome = binary_elementwise(outcome_self, outcome_other, op,
 222                                             *args, **kwargs)
 223            data[new_outcome] += weight_self * weight_other
 224        return icepool.Die(data)
 225
 226    # Basic access.
 227
 228    def outcomes(self) -> Sequence:
 229        """Returns the sequence of sorted outcomes of the die. """
 230        return self._data.keys()
 231
 232    def __contains__(self, outcome) -> bool:
 233        return outcome in self._data
 234
 235    def num_outcomes(self) -> int:
 236        """Returns the number of outcomes (including those with zero weight). """
 237        return len(self._data)
 238
 239    @cached_property
 240    def _outcome_len(self) -> int | None:
 241        result = None
 242        for outcome in self.outcomes():
 243            try:
 244                if result is None:
 245                    result = len(outcome)
 246                elif len(outcome) != result:
 247                    return None
 248            except TypeError:
 249                return None
 250        return result
 251
 252    def outcome_len(self) -> int | None:
 253        """Returns the common length of the outcomes.
 254
 255        If any outcome has no length, the outcomes have mixed length, or the
 256        die is empty, the result is `None`.
 257        """
 258        return self._outcome_len
 259
 260    def is_empty(self) -> bool:
 261        """Returns `True` if this die has no outcomes. """
 262        return self.num_outcomes() == 0
 263
 264    def weights(self) -> Sequence[int]:
 265        """Returns the sequence of the weights of the die in outcome order. """
 266        return self._data.values()
 267
 268    def has_zero_weights(self) -> bool:
 269        """Returns `True` iff `self` contains at least one outcome with zero weight. """
 270        return self._data.has_zero_values()
 271
 272    def items(self) -> Sequence[tuple[Any, int]]:
 273        """Returns the sequence of sorted outcome, weight pairs. """
 274        return self._data.items()
 275
 276    # Weights.
 277
 278    @cached_property
 279    def _denominator(self) -> int:
 280        return sum(self._data.values())
 281
 282    def denominator(self) -> int:
 283        """The total weight of all outcomes. """
 284        return self._denominator
 285
 286    total_weight = denominator
 287
 288    @cached_property
 289    def _pmf(self):
 290        return tuple(weight / self.denominator() for weight in self.weights())
 291
 292    def pmf(self, percent: bool = False):
 293        """Probability mass function. The probability of rolling each outcome in order.
 294
 295        Args:
 296            percent: If set, the results will be in percent (i.e. total of 100.0).
 297                Otherwise, the total will be 1.0.
 298        """
 299        if percent:
 300            return tuple(100.0 * x for x in self._pmf)
 301        else:
 302            return self._pmf
 303
 304    @cached_property
 305    def _cweights(self) -> Sequence[int]:
 306        return tuple(itertools.accumulate(self.weights()))
 307
 308    def cweights(self) -> Sequence[int]:
 309        """Cumulative weights. The weight <= each outcome in order. """
 310        return self._cweights
 311
 312    @cached_property
 313    def _sweights(self) -> Sequence[int]:
 314        return tuple(
 315            itertools.accumulate(self.weights()[:-1],
 316                                 operator.sub,
 317                                 initial=self.denominator()))
 318
 319    def sweights(self) -> Sequence[int]:
 320        """Survival weights. The weight >= each outcome in order. """
 321        return self._sweights
 322
 323    @cached_property
 324    def _cdf(self):
 325        return tuple(weight / self.denominator() for weight in self.cweights())
 326
 327    def cdf(self, percent: bool = False):
 328        """Cumulative distribution function. The chance of rolling <= each outcome in order.
 329
 330        Args:
 331            percent: If set, the results will be in percent (i.e. total of 100.0).
 332                Otherwise, the total will be 1.0.
 333        """
 334        if percent:
 335            return tuple(100.0 * x for x in self._cdf)
 336        else:
 337            return self._cdf
 338
 339    @cached_property
 340    def _sf(self):
 341        return tuple(weight / self.denominator() for weight in self.sweights())
 342
 343    def sf(self, percent: bool = False):
 344        """Survival function. The chance of rolling >= each outcome in order.
 345
 346        Args:
 347            percent: If set, the results will be in percent (i.e. total of 100.0).
 348                Otherwise, the total will be 1.0.
 349        """
 350        if percent:
 351            return tuple(100.0 * x for x in self._sf)
 352        else:
 353            return self._sf
 354
 355    def weight_eq(self, outcome) -> int:
 356        """Returns the weight of a single outcome, or 0 if not present. """
 357        return self._data[outcome]
 358
 359    def weight_ne(self, outcome) -> int:
 360        """Returns the weight != a single outcome. """
 361        return self.denominator() - self.weight_eq(outcome)
 362
 363    def weight_le(self, outcome) -> int:
 364        """Returns the weight <= a single outcome. """
 365        index = bisect.bisect_right(self.outcomes(), outcome) - 1
 366        if index < 0:
 367            return 0
 368        return self.cweights()[index]
 369
 370    def weight_lt(self, outcome) -> int:
 371        """Returns the weight < a single outcome. """
 372        index = bisect.bisect_left(self.outcomes(), outcome) - 1
 373        if index < 0:
 374            return 0
 375        return self.cweights()[index]
 376
 377    def weight_ge(self, outcome) -> int:
 378        """Returns the weight >= a single outcome. """
 379        index = bisect.bisect_left(self.outcomes(), outcome)
 380        if index >= self.num_outcomes():
 381            return 0
 382        return self.sweights()[index]
 383
 384    def weight_gt(self, outcome) -> int:
 385        """Returns the weight > a single outcome. """
 386        index = bisect.bisect_right(self.outcomes(), outcome)
 387        if index >= self.num_outcomes():
 388            return 0
 389        return self.sweights()[index]
 390
 391    def probability(self, outcome):
 392        """Returns the probability of a single outcome. """
 393        return self.weight_eq(outcome) / self.denominator()
 394
 395    # Scalar statistics.
 396
 397    def mode(self) -> tuple:
 398        """Returns a tuple containing the most common outcome(s) of the die.
 399
 400        These are sorted from lowest to highest.
 401        """
 402        return tuple(outcome for outcome, weight in self.items()
 403                     if weight == self.modal_weight())
 404
 405    def modal_weight(self) -> int:
 406        """The highest weight of any single outcome. """
 407        return max(self.weights())
 408
 409    def ks_stat(self, other):
 410        """Kolmogorov–Smirnov stat. The maximum absolute difference between CDFs. """
 411        a, b = icepool.align(self, other)
 412        return max(abs(a - b) for a, b in zip(a.cdf(), b.cdf()))
 413
 414    def cvm_stat(self, other):
 415        """Cramér-von Mises stat. The sum-of-squares difference between CDFs. """
 416        a, b = icepool.align(self, other)
 417        return sum((a - b)**2 for a, b in zip(a.cdf(), b.cdf()))
 418
 419    def median_left(self):
 420        """Returns the median.
 421
 422        If the median lies between two outcomes, returns the lower of the two. """
 423        return self.ppf_left(1, 2)
 424
 425    def median_right(self):
 426        """Returns the median.
 427
 428        If the median lies between two outcomes, returns the higher of the two. """
 429        return self.ppf_right(1, 2)
 430
 431    def median(self):
 432        """Returns the median.
 433
 434        If the median lies between two outcomes, returns the mean of the two.
 435        This will fail if the outcomes do not support division;
 436        in this case, use `median_left` or `median_right` instead.
 437        """
 438        return self.ppf(1, 2)
 439
 440    def ppf_left(self, n: int, d: int = 100):
 441        """Returns a quantile, `n / d` of the way through the cdf.
 442
 443        If the result lies between two outcomes, returns the lower of the two.
 444        """
 445        index = bisect.bisect_left(self.cweights(),
 446                                   (n * self.denominator() + d - 1) // d)
 447        if index >= self.num_outcomes():
 448            return self.max_outcome()
 449        return self.outcomes()[index]
 450
 451    def ppf_right(self, n: int, d: int = 100):
 452        """Returns a quantile, `n / d` of the way through the cdf.
 453
 454        If the result lies between two outcomes, returns the higher of the two.
 455        """
 456        index = bisect.bisect_right(self.cweights(),
 457                                    n * self.denominator() // d)
 458        if index >= self.num_outcomes():
 459            return self.max_outcome()
 460        return self.outcomes()[index]
 461
 462    def ppf(self, n: int, d: int = 100):
 463        """Returns a quantile, `n / d` of the way through the cdf.
 464
 465        If the result lies between two outcomes, returns the mean of the two.
 466        This will fail if the outcomes do not support division;
 467        in this case, use `ppf_left` or `ppf_right` instead.
 468        """
 469        return (self.ppf_left(n, d) + self.ppf_right(n, d)) / 2
 470
 471    def mean(self):
 472        return sum(
 473            outcome * p for outcome, p in zip(self.outcomes(), self.pmf()))
 474
 475    def variance(self):
 476        mean = self.mean()
 477        mean_of_squares = sum(
 478            p * outcome**2 for outcome, p in zip(self.outcomes(), self.pmf()))
 479        return mean_of_squares - mean * mean
 480
 481    def standard_deviation(self):
 482        return math.sqrt(self.variance())
 483
 484    sd = standard_deviation
 485
 486    def standardized_moment(self, k: int):
 487        sd = self.standard_deviation()
 488        mean = self.mean()
 489        ev = sum(p * (outcome - mean)**k
 490                 for outcome, p in zip(self.outcomes(), self.pmf()))
 491        return ev / (sd**k)
 492
 493    def skewness(self):
 494        return self.standardized_moment(3.0)
 495
 496    def excess_kurtosis(self):
 497        return self.standardized_moment(4.0) - 3.0
 498
 499    # Joint statistics.
 500
 501    def covariance(self, i: int, j: int):
 502        mean_i = self[i].mean()
 503        mean_j = self[j].mean()
 504        return sum((outcome[i] - mean_i) * (outcome[j] - mean_j) * weight
 505                   for outcome, weight in self.items()) / self.denominator()
 506
 507    def correlation(self, i: int, j: int):
 508        sd_i = self[i].standard_deviation()
 509        sd_j = self[j].standard_deviation()
 510        return self.covariance(i, j) / (sd_i * sd_j)
 511
 512    # Weight management.
 513
 514    def reduce_weights(self) -> 'Die':
 515        """Divides all weights by their greatest common denominator. """
 516        return icepool.Die(self._data.reduce())
 517
 518    def scale_weights(self, scale: int) -> 'Die':
 519        """Multiplies all weights by a constant. """
 520        if scale < 0:
 521            raise ValueError('Weights cannot be scaled by a negative number.')
 522        if scale == 1:
 523            return self
 524        data = {outcome: scale * weight for outcome, weight in self.items()}
 525        return icepool.Die(data)
 526
 527    # Rerolls and other outcome management.
 528
 529    def min_outcome(self):
 530        """Returns the minimum possible outcome of this die."""
 531        return self.outcomes()[0]
 532
 533    def max_outcome(self):
 534        """Returns the maximum possible outcome of this die."""
 535        return self.outcomes()[-1]
 536
 537    def nearest_le(self, outcome):
 538        """Returns the nearest outcome that is <= the argument.
 539
 540        Returns `None` if there is no such outcome.
 541        """
 542        index = bisect.bisect_right(self.outcomes(), outcome) - 1
 543        if index < 0:
 544            return None
 545        return self.outcomes()[index]
 546
 547    def nearest_ge(self, outcome):
 548        """Returns the nearest outcome that is >= the argument.
 549
 550        Returns `None` if there is no such outcome.
 551        """
 552        index = bisect.bisect_left(self.outcomes(), outcome)
 553        if index >= self.num_outcomes():
 554            return None
 555        return self.outcomes()[index]
 556
 557    def reroll(self,
 558               outcomes: Callable[..., bool] | Container | None = None,
 559               *,
 560               max_depth: int | None = None,
 561               star: int = 0) -> 'Die':
 562        """Rerolls the given outcomes.
 563
 564        Args:
 565            outcomes: Selects which outcomes to reroll. Options:
 566                * A callable that takes an outcome and returns `True` if it
 567                    should be rerolled.
 568                * A container of outcomes to reroll.
 569                * If not provided, the min outcome will be rerolled.
 570            max_depth: The maximum number of times to reroll.
 571                If omitted, rerolls an unlimited number of times.
 572            star: If set to `True` or 1, outcomes will be unpacked as
 573                `*outcome` before giving it to the `outcomes` function.
 574                If `outcomes` is not a callable, this has no effect.
 575
 576        Returns:
 577            A die representing the reroll.
 578            If the reroll would never terminate, the result has no outcomes.
 579        """
 580        if outcomes is None:
 581            outcomes = {self.min_outcome()}
 582        elif callable(outcomes):
 583            if star:
 584                outcomes = {
 585                    outcome for outcome in self.outcomes() if outcomes(*outcome)
 586                }
 587            else:
 588                outcomes = {
 589                    outcome for outcome in self.outcomes() if outcomes(outcome)
 590                }
 591
 592        if max_depth is None:
 593            data = {
 594                outcome: weight
 595                for outcome, weight in self.items()
 596                if outcome not in outcomes
 597            }
 598        else:
 599            total_reroll_weight = sum(
 600                weight for outcome, weight in self.items()
 601                if outcome in outcomes)
 602            rerollable_factor = total_reroll_weight**max_depth
 603            stop_factor = (self.denominator()**max_depth +
 604                           total_reroll_weight**max_depth)
 605            data = {
 606                outcome:
 607                (rerollable_factor *
 608                 weight if outcome in outcomes else stop_factor * weight)
 609                for outcome, weight in self.items()
 610            }
 611        return icepool.Die(data)
 612
 613    def reroll_until(self,
 614                     outcomes: Callable[..., bool] | Container,
 615                     *,
 616                     max_depth: int | None = None,
 617                     star: int = 0) -> 'Die':
 618        """Rerolls until getting one of the given outcomes.
 619
 620        Essentially the complement of `reroll()`.
 621
 622        Args:
 623            outcomes: Selects which outcomes to reroll until. Options:
 624                * A callable that takes an outcome and returns `True` if it
 625                    should be accepted.
 626                * A container of outcomes to reroll until.
 627            max_depth: The maximum number of times to reroll.
 628                If omitted, rerolls an unlimited number of times.
 629            star: If set to `True` or 1, outcomes will be unpacked as
 630                `*outcome` before giving it to the `outcomes` function.
 631                If `outcomes` is not a callable, this has no effect.
 632
 633        Returns:
 634            A die representing the reroll.
 635            If the reroll would never terminate, the result has no outcomes.
 636        """
 637        if callable(outcomes):
 638            if star:
 639                not_outcomes = {
 640                    outcome for outcome in self.outcomes()
 641                    if not outcomes(*outcome)
 642                }
 643            else:
 644                not_outcomes = {
 645                    outcome for outcome in self.outcomes()
 646                    if not outcomes(outcome)
 647                }
 648        else:
 649            not_outcomes = {
 650                not_outcome for not_outcome in self.outcomes()
 651                if not_outcome not in outcomes
 652            }
 653        return self.reroll(not_outcomes, max_depth=max_depth)
 654
 655    def truncate(self, min_outcome=None, max_outcome=None) -> 'Die':
 656        """Truncates the outcomes of this die to the given range.
 657
 658        The endpoints are included in the result if applicable.
 659        If one of the arguments is not provided, that side will not be truncated.
 660
 661        This effectively rerolls outcomes outside the given range.
 662        If instead you want to replace those outcomes with the nearest endpoint,
 663        use `clip()`.
 664
 665        Not to be confused with `trunc(die)`, which performs integer truncation
 666        on each outcome.
 667        """
 668        if min_outcome is not None:
 669            start = bisect.bisect_left(self.outcomes(), min_outcome)
 670        else:
 671            start = None
 672        if max_outcome is not None:
 673            stop = bisect.bisect_right(self.outcomes(), max_outcome)
 674        else:
 675            stop = None
 676        data = {k: v for k, v in self.items()[start:stop]}
 677        return icepool.Die(data)
 678
 679    def clip(self, min_outcome=None, max_outcome=None) -> 'Die':
 680        """Clips the outcomes of this die to the given values.
 681
 682        The endpoints are included in the result if applicable.
 683        If one of the arguments is not provided, that side will not be clipped.
 684
 685        This is not the same as rerolling outcomes beyond this range;
 686        the outcome is simply adjusted to fit within the range.
 687        This will typically cause some weight to bunch up at the endpoint.
 688        If you want to reroll outcomes beyond this range, use `truncate()`.
 689        """
 690        data: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
 691        for outcome, weight in self.items():
 692            if min_outcome is not None and outcome <= min_outcome:
 693                data[min_outcome] += weight
 694            elif max_outcome is not None and outcome >= max_outcome:
 695                data[max_outcome] += weight
 696            else:
 697                data[outcome] += weight
 698        return icepool.Die(data)
 699
 700    def set_range(self,
 701                  min_outcome: int | None = None,
 702                  max_outcome: int | None = None) -> 'Die':
 703        """Sets the outcomes of this die to the given `int` range (inclusive).
 704
 705        Args:
 706            min_outcome: The min outcome of the result.
 707                If omitted, the min outcome of this die will be used.
 708            max_outcome: The max outcome of the result.
 709                If omitted, the max outcome of this die will be used.
 710        """
 711        if min_outcome is None:
 712            min_outcome = self.min_outcome()
 713        if max_outcome is None:
 714            max_outcome = self.max_outcome()
 715
 716        return self.set_outcomes(range(min_outcome, max_outcome + 1))
 717
 718    def set_outcomes(self, outcomes) -> 'Die':
 719        """Sets the set of outcomes to the argument.
 720
 721        This may remove outcomes (if they are not present in the argument)
 722        and/or add zero-weight outcomes (if they are not present in this die).
 723        """
 724        data = {x: self.weight_eq(x) for x in outcomes}
 725        return icepool.Die(data)
 726
 727    def trim(self) -> 'Die':
 728        """Removes all zero-weight outcomes. """
 729        data = {k: v for k, v in self.items() if v > 0}
 730        return icepool.Die(data)
 731
 732    @cached_property
 733    def _popped_min(self) -> tuple['Die', int]:
 734        die = icepool.Die(self.outcomes()[1:], self.weights()[1:])
 735        return die, self.weights()[0]
 736
 737    def _pop_min(self) -> tuple['Die', int]:
 738        """Removes the min outcome and return the result, along with the popped outcome, and the popped weight.
 739
 740        Raises:
 741            `IndexError` if this die has no outcome to pop.
 742        """
 743        return self._popped_min
 744
 745    @cached_property
 746    def _popped_max(self) -> tuple['Die', int]:
 747        die = icepool.Die(self.outcomes()[:-1], self.weights()[:-1])
 748        return die, self.weights()[-1]
 749
 750    def _pop_max(self) -> tuple['Die', int]:
 751        """Removes the max outcome and return the result, along with the popped outcome, and the popped weight.
 752
 753        Raises:
 754            `IndexError` if this die has no outcome to pop.
 755        """
 756        return self._popped_max
 757
 758    # Mixtures.
 759
 760    def sub(self,
 761            repl: Mapping | Callable[[Any], Any] | Sequence,
 762            /,
 763            *extra_args,
 764            max_depth: int | None = 1,
 765            star: int = 0,
 766            denominator_method: str = 'lcm') -> 'Die':
 767        """Changes outcomes of the die to other outcomes.
 768
 769        You can think of this as `sub`stituting outcomes of this die for other
 770        outcomes or dice. Or, as executing a `sub`routine based on the roll of
 771        this die.
 772
 773        Args:
 774            repl: One of the following:
 775                * A map from old outcomes to new outcomes.
 776                    Unmapped old outcomes stay the same.
 777                * A callable mapping old outcomes to new outcomes.
 778                * A sequence specifying new outcomes in order.
 779                The new outcomes may be dice rather than just single outcomes.
 780                The special value `icepool.Reroll` will reroll that old outcome.
 781            *extra_args: These will be supplied to `repl` as extra positional
 782                arguments after the outcome argument(s). `extra_args` can only
 783                be supplied if `repl` is callable.
 784            max_depth: `sub()` will be repeated with the same argument on the
 785                result this many times. If set to `None`, this will repeat until
 786                a fixed point is reached.
 787            star: If set to `True` or 1, outcomes will be unpacked as
 788                `*outcome` before giving it to the `repl` function. If `repl`
 789                is not a callable, this has no effect.
 790            denominator_method: As `icepool.Die()`.
 791
 792        Returns:
 793            The relabeled die.
 794
 795        Raises:
 796            `ValueError` if `extra_args` are supplied with a non-callable `repl`.
 797        """
 798        if extra_args and not callable(repl):
 799            raise ValueError(
 800                'Extra positional arguments are only valid if repl is callable.'
 801            )
 802
 803        if max_depth == 0:
 804            return self
 805        elif max_depth == 1:
 806            if isinstance(repl, Mapping):
 807                final_repl = [(repl[outcome] if outcome in repl else outcome)
 808                              for outcome in self.outcomes()]
 809            elif callable(repl):
 810                if star:
 811                    final_repl = [
 812                        repl(*outcome, *extra_args)
 813                        for outcome in self.outcomes()
 814                    ]
 815                else:
 816                    final_repl = [
 817                        repl(outcome, *extra_args)
 818                        for outcome in self.outcomes()
 819                    ]
 820            else:
 821                final_repl = list(repl)
 822
 823            return icepool.Die(final_repl,
 824                               self.weights(),
 825                               denominator_method=denominator_method)
 826        elif max_depth is not None:
 827            next = self.sub(repl,
 828                            max_depth=1,
 829                            denominator_method=denominator_method)
 830            return next.sub(repl,
 831                            max_depth=max_depth - 1,
 832                            denominator_method=denominator_method)
 833        else:
 834            # Seek fixed point.
 835            next = self.sub(repl,
 836                            max_depth=1,
 837                            denominator_method=denominator_method)
 838            if self.reduce_weights().equals(next.reduce_weights()):
 839                return self
 840            else:
 841                return next.sub(repl,
 842                                max_depth=None,
 843                                denominator_method=denominator_method)
 844
 845    def explode(self,
 846                outcomes: Container | Callable[..., bool] | None = None,
 847                *,
 848                max_depth: int = 9,
 849                star: int = 0) -> 'Die':
 850        """Causes outcomes to be rolled again and added to the total.
 851
 852        Args:
 853            outcomes: Which outcomes to explode. Options:
 854                * An container of outcomes to explode.
 855                * A callable that takes an outcome and returns `True` if it
 856                    should be exploded.
 857                * If not supplied, the max outcome will explode.
 858            max_depth: The maximum number of additional dice to roll.
 859                If not supplied, a default value will be used.
 860            star: If set to `True` or 1, outcomes will be unpacked as
 861                `*outcome` before giving it to the `outcomes` function.
 862                If `outcomes` is not a callable, this has no effect.
 863        """
 864        if outcomes is None:
 865            outcomes = {self.max_outcome()}
 866        elif callable(outcomes):
 867            if star:
 868                outcomes = {
 869                    outcome for outcome in self.outcomes() if outcomes(*outcome)
 870                }
 871            else:
 872                outcomes = {
 873                    outcome for outcome in self.outcomes() if outcomes(outcome)
 874                }
 875        else:
 876            if not outcomes:
 877                return self
 878
 879        if max_depth < 0:
 880            raise ValueError('max_depth cannot be negative.')
 881        elif max_depth == 0:
 882            return self
 883
 884        tail_die = self.explode(outcomes=outcomes, max_depth=max_depth - 1)
 885
 886        def sub_func(outcome):
 887            if outcome in outcomes:
 888                return outcome + tail_die
 889            else:
 890                return outcome
 891
 892        return self.sub(sub_func, denominator_method='lcm')
 893
 894    def if_else(self,
 895                outcome_if_true,
 896                outcome_if_false,
 897                /,
 898                *,
 899                denominator_method: str = 'lcm') -> 'Die':
 900        """Ternary conditional operator.
 901
 902        This replaces truthy outcomes with the first argument and falsy outcomes
 903        with the second argument.
 904        """
 905        return self.bool().sub(lambda x: outcome_if_true
 906                               if x else outcome_if_false,
 907                               denominator_method=denominator_method)
 908
 909    # Pools and sums.
 910
 911    @cached_property
 912    def _sum_cache(self) -> MutableMapping[int, 'Die']:
 913        return {}
 914
 915    def _sum_all(self, num_dice: int) -> 'Die':
 916        """Roll this die `num_dice` times and sum the results.
 917
 918        If `num_dice` is negative, roll the die `abs(num_dice)` times and negate
 919        the result.
 920
 921        If you instead want to replace tuple (or other sequence) outcomes with
 922        their sum, use `die.sub(sum)`.
 923        """
 924        if num_dice in self._sum_cache:
 925            return self._sum_cache[num_dice]
 926
 927        if num_dice < 0:
 928            result = -self._sum_all(-num_dice)
 929        elif num_dice == 0:
 930            result = self.zero()
 931        elif num_dice == 1:
 932            result = self
 933        else:
 934            # Binary split seems to perform much worse.
 935            result = self + self._sum_all(num_dice - 1)
 936
 937        self._sum_cache[num_dice] = result
 938        return result
 939
 940    def __matmul__(self, other) -> 'Die':
 941        """Roll the left die, then roll the right die that many times and sum the outcomes."""
 942        other = icepool.Die([other])
 943
 944        data: MutableMapping[int, Any] = defaultdict(int)
 945
 946        max_abs_die_count = max(abs(self.min_outcome()),
 947                                abs(self.max_outcome()))
 948        for die_count, die_count_weight in self.items():
 949            factor = other.denominator()**(max_abs_die_count - abs(die_count))
 950            subresult = other._sum_all(die_count)
 951            for outcome, subresult_weight in subresult.items():
 952                data[outcome] += subresult_weight * die_count_weight * factor
 953
 954        return icepool.Die(data)
 955
 956    def __rmatmul__(self, other) -> 'Die':
 957        """Roll the left die, then roll the right die that many times and sum the outcomes."""
 958        other = icepool.Die([other])
 959        return other.__matmul__(self)
 960
 961    def pool(self, num_dice: int = 1) -> 'icepool.Pool':
 962        """Creates a pool from this die.
 963
 964        Args:
 965            num_dice: The number of copies of this die to put in the pool.
 966        """
 967        return icepool.Pool({self: num_dice})
 968
 969    def keep_highest(self,
 970                     num_dice: int,
 971                     num_keep: int = 1,
 972                     num_drop: int = 0) -> 'Die':
 973        """Roll several of this die and sum the sorted results from the highest.
 974
 975        Args:
 976            num_dice: The number of dice to roll. All dice will have the same
 977                outcomes as `self`.
 978            num_keep: The number of dice to keep.
 979            num_drop: If provided, this many highest dice will be dropped before
 980                keeping.
 981
 982        Returns:
 983            A die representing the probability distribution of the sum.
 984        """
 985        if num_keep == 1 and num_drop == 0:
 986            return self._keep_highest_single(num_dice)
 987        start = -(num_keep + (num_drop or 0))
 988        stop = -num_drop if num_drop > 0 else None
 989        post_roll_counts = slice(start, stop)
 990        return self.pool(num_dice)[post_roll_counts].sum()
 991
 992    def _keep_highest_single(self, num_dice: int) -> 'Die':
 993        """Faster algorithm for keeping just the single highest die. """
 994        if num_dice == 0:
 995            return self.zero()
 996        return icepool.from_cweights(self.outcomes(),
 997                                     [x**num_dice for x in self.cweights()])
 998
 999    def keep_lowest(self,
1000                    num_dice: int,
1001                    num_keep: int = 1,
1002                    num_drop: int = 0) -> 'Die':
1003        """Roll several of this die and sum the sorted results from the lowest.
1004
1005        Args:
1006            num_dice: The number of dice to roll. All dice will have the same
1007                outcomes as `self`.
1008            num_keep: The number of dice to keep.
1009            num_drop: If provided, this many lowest dice will be dropped before
1010                keeping.
1011
1012        Returns:
1013            A die representing the probability distribution of the sum.
1014        """
1015        if num_keep == 1 and num_drop == 0:
1016            return self._keep_lowest_single(num_dice)
1017
1018        start = num_drop if num_drop > 0 else None
1019        stop = num_keep + (num_drop or 0)
1020        post_roll_counts = slice(start, stop)
1021        return self.pool(num_dice)[post_roll_counts].sum()
1022
1023    def _keep_lowest_single(self, num_dice: int) -> 'Die':
1024        """Faster algorithm for keeping just the single lowest die. """
1025        if num_dice == 0:
1026            return self.zero()
1027        return icepool.from_sweights(self.outcomes(),
1028                                     [x**num_dice for x in self.sweights()])
1029
1030    # Unary operators.
1031
1032    def __neg__(self) -> 'Die':
1033        return self.unary_op(operator.neg)
1034
1035    def __pos__(self) -> 'Die':
1036        return self.unary_op(operator.pos)
1037
1038    def __invert__(self) -> 'Die':
1039        return self.unary_op(operator.invert)
1040
1041    def abs(self) -> 'Die':
1042        return self.unary_op(operator.abs)
1043
1044    __abs__ = abs
1045
1046    def round(self, ndigits: int = None) -> 'Die':
1047        return self.unary_op(round, ndigits)
1048
1049    __round__ = round
1050
1051    def trunc(self) -> 'Die':
1052        return self.unary_op(math.trunc)
1053
1054    __trunc__ = trunc
1055
1056    def floor(self) -> 'Die':
1057        return self.unary_op(math.floor)
1058
1059    __floor__ = floor
1060
1061    def ceil(self) -> 'Die':
1062        return self.unary_op(math.ceil)
1063
1064    __ceil__ = ceil
1065
1066    def marginal(self, index_or_slice, /) -> 'Die':
1067        """Marginal distribution; equivalently, indexes/slices outcomes.
1068
1069        You can use the `[]` operator for the same effect.
1070
1071        Note that `[]` has a different, non-standard meaning for pools.
1072        """
1073        return self.unary_op_non_elementwise(operator.getitem, index_or_slice)
1074
1075    __getitem__ = marginal
1076
1077    @staticmethod
1078    def _zero(x):
1079        return type(x)()
1080
1081    def zero(self) -> 'Die':
1082        """Zeros all outcomes of this die.
1083
1084        This is done by calling the constructor for each outcome's type with no
1085        arguments.
1086
1087        The result will have the same denominator as this die.
1088
1089        Raises:
1090            `ValueError` if the zeros did not resolve to a single outcome.
1091        """
1092        result = self.unary_op(Die._zero)
1093        if result.num_outcomes() != 1:
1094            raise ValueError('zero() did not resolve to a single outcome.')
1095        return result
1096
1097    def zero_outcome(self):
1098        """Returns a zero-outcome for this die.
1099
1100        E.g. `0` for a die whose outcomes are `int`s.
1101        """
1102        return self.zero().outcomes()[0]
1103
1104    def bool(self) -> 'Die':
1105        """Takes `bool()` of all outcomes.
1106
1107        Note the die as a whole is not considered to have a truth value.
1108        """
1109        return self.unary_op(bool)
1110
1111    # Binary operators.
1112
1113    def __add__(self, other) -> 'Die':
1114        other = icepool.Die([other])

1229    def __eq__(self, other):
1230        other = icepool.Die([other])
1231
1232        def data_callback():
1233            data_die = self.binary_op(other, operator.eq)
1234            return data_die._data
1235
1236        truth_value = self.equals(other)
1237
1238        return icepool.DieWithTruth(data_callback, truth_value)
1239
1240    def __ne__(self, other):
1241        other = icepool.Die([other])
1242
1243        def data_callback():
1244            data_die = self.binary_op(other, operator.ne)
1245            return data_die._data
1246
1247        truth_value = not self.equals(other)
1248
1249        return icepool.DieWithTruth(data_callback, truth_value)

1251    @staticmethod
1252    def _sign(x) -> int:
1253        z = Die._zero(x)
1254        if x > z:
1255            return 1
1256        elif x < z:
1257            return -1
1258        else:
1259            return 0
1260
1261    def sign(self) -> 'Die':
1262        """Outcomes become 1 if greater than `zero()`, -1 if less than `zero()`, and 0 otherwise.
1263
1264        Note that for `float`s, +0.0, -0.0, and nan all become 0.
1265        """
1266        return self.unary_op(Die._sign)
1267
1268    @staticmethod
1269    def _cmp(x, y) -> int:
1270        return Die._sign(x - y)
1271
1272    def cmp(self, other) -> 'Die':
1273        """Returns a die with possible outcomes 1, -1, and 0.
1274
1275        The weights are equal to the positive outcome of `self > other`,
1276        `self < other`, and the remainder respectively.
1277        """
1278        return self.binary_op(other, Die._cmp)

1280    # Rolling.
1281
1282    def sample(self):
1283        """Returns a random roll of this die.
1284
1285        Do not use for security purposes.
1286        """
1287        # We don't use random.choices since that is based on floats rather than ints.
1288        r = random.randrange(self.denominator())
1289        index = bisect.bisect_right(self.cweights(), r)
1290        return self.outcomes()[index]

1331
1332    def equals(self, other, *, reduce=False):
1333        """Returns `True` iff both dice have the same outcomes and weights.
1334
1335        Truth value does NOT matter.
1336
1337        If one die has a zero-weight outcome and the other die does not contain
1338        that outcome, they are treated as unequal by this function.
1339
1340        The `==` and `!=` operators have a dual purpose; they return a die
1341        with a truth value determined by this method.
1342        Only dice returned by these methods have a truth value. The data of
1343        these dice is lazily evaluated since the caller may only be interested
1344        in the truth value.
1345
1346        Args:
1347            reduce: If `True`, the dice will be reduced before comparing.
1348                Otherwise, e.g. a 2:2 coin is not `equals()` to a 1:1 coin.
1349        """
1350        try:
1351            other = icepool.Die([other])
1352        except ValueError:
1353            return False
1354
1355        if reduce:
1356            return self.reduce_weights().key_tuple() == other.reduce_weights(
1357            ).key_tuple()
1358        else:
1359            return self.key_tuple() == other.key_tuple()
1360
1361    # Strings.
1362
1363    def __repr__(self) -> str:
1364        inner = ', '.join(
1365            f'{outcome}: {weight}' for outcome, weight in self.items())
1366        return type(self).__qualname__ + '({' + inner + '})'
1367
1368    def __str__(self) -> str:
1369        return f'{self}'
1370
1371    def format(self, format_spec: str, **kwargs) -> str:
1372        """Formats this die as a string.
1373
1374        `format_spec` should start with the output format,
1375        which is either `md` (Markdown) or `csv` (comma-separated values),
1376        followed by a ':' character.
1377
1378        After this, zero or more columns should follow. Options are:
1379
1380        * `o`: Outcomes.
1381        * `*o`: Outcomes, unpacked if applicable.
1382        * `w==`, `w<=`, `w>=`: Weights ==, <=, or >= each outcome.
1383        * `%==`, `%<=`, `%>=`: Chance (%) ==, <=, or >= each outcome.
1384
1385        Columns may optionally be separated using ` ` (space) or `|` characters.
1386
1387        The default is `'md:*o|w==|%=='`, with the weight column being omitted
1388        if any weight exceeds 10**30.
1389        """
1390        if len(format_spec) == 0:
1391            format_spec = 'md:*o'
1392            if not self.is_empty() and self.modal_weight() < 10**30:
1393                format_spec += 'w=='
1394            format_spec += '%=='
1395
1396        format_spec = format_spec.replace('|', '')
1397
1398        output_format, format_spec = format_spec.split(':')
1399        if output_format == 'md':
1400            return icepool.die.format.markdown(self, format_spec)
1401        elif output_format == 'csv':
1402            return icepool.die.format.csv(self, format_spec, **kwargs)
1403        else:
1404            raise ValueError(f"Unsupported output format '{output_format}'")
1405
1406    def __format__(self, format_spec: str) -> str:
1407        return self.format(format_spec)

An immutable mapping of outcomes to nonnegative int weights.

Dice are immutable. Methods do not modify the die in-place; rather they return a die representing the result.

It is (mostly) well-defined to have a die with zero-weight outcomes, even though this is not a proper probability distribution. These can be useful in a few cases, such as:

  • Pool and EvalPool will iterate through zero-weight outcomes with 0 count, rather than None or skipping that outcome.
  • icepool.align() and the like are convenient for making dice share the same set of outcomes.

However, zero-weight outcomes have a computational cost like any other outcome. Unless you have a specific use case in mind, it's best to leave them out.

Most operators and methods will not introduce zero-weight outcomes if their arguments do not have any.

It's also possible to have "empty" dice with no outcomes at all, though these have little use other than being sentinel values.

Die( outcomes: collections.abc.Mapping[typing.Any, int] | collections.abc.Sequence, times: collections.abc.Sequence[int] | int = 1, denominator_method: str = 'lcm') 
 50    def __new__(cls,
 51                outcomes: Mapping[Any, int] | Sequence,
 52                times: Sequence[int] | int = 1,
 53                denominator_method: str = 'lcm') -> 'Die':
 54        """Constructor for a die.
 55
 56        Don't confuse this with `d()`:
 57
 58        * `Die([6])`: A die that always rolls the `int` 6.
 59        * `d(6)`: A d6.
 60
 61        Also, don't confuse this with `Pool()`:
 62
 63        * `Die([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6])`: A d6.
 64        * `Pool([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6])`: A pool of six dice that always rolls one
 65            of each number.
 66
 67        Here are some different ways of constructing a d6:
 68
 69        * Just import it: `from icepool import d6`
 70        * Use the `d()` function: `icepool.d(6)`
 71        * Use a d6 that you already have: `Die(d6)`
 72        * Mix a d3 and a d3+3: `Die(d3, d3+3)`
 73        * Use a dict: `Die({1:1, 2:1, 3:1, 4:1, 5:1, 6:1})`
 74        * Give the faces as args: `Die(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6)`
 75
 76        All weights must be non-negative, though they can be zero.
 77
 78        Args:
 79            outcomes: The outcomes of the die. This can be one of the following:
 80                * A dict mapping outcomes to weights.
 81                * A sequence of outcomes. Each element will have the same total
 82                    weight.
 83
 84                Each outcome may be one of the following:
 85                * A `Die`. The outcomes of the die will be "flattened" into the
 86                    result; a `Die` will never contain a `Die` as an outcome.
 87                * A dict-like that maps outcomes to weights.
 88                    The outcomes of the dict-like will be "flattened" into the
 89                    result. This option will be taken in preference to treating
 90                    the dict-like itself as an outcome even if the dict-like
 91                    itself is hashable and totally orderable.
 92                * A tuple of outcomes. Operators on dice with tuple outcomes
 93                    are performed element-wise. See `Die.unary_op` and
 94                    `Die.binary_op` for details.
 95
 96                    Any tuple elements that are dice or dicts will expand the
 97                    tuple according to their independent joint distribution.
 98                    For example, `(d6, d6)` will expand to 36 ordered tuples
 99                    with weight 1 each. Use this carefully since it may create a
100                    large number of outcomes.
101                * `icepool.Reroll`, which will drop itself
102                    and the corresponding element of `times` from consideration.
103                    If inside a tuple, the tuple will be dropped.
104                * Anything else, including non-tuple sequences, will be treated
105                    as a single outcome. Each outcome must be hashable, and the
106                    set of outcomes must be totally orderable (after expansion).
107                    The same outcome can appear multiple times, in which case
108                    the corresponding weights will be accumulated.
109            times: Multiplies the weight of each element of `outcomes`.
110                `times` can either be a sequence of the same length as
111                `outcomes` or a single `int` to apply to all elements of
112                `outcomes`.
113            denominator_method: How to determine the denominator of the result
114                if the arguments themselves contain weights. This is also used
115                for dict-like arguments. From greatest to least:
116                * 'prod': Product of the individual argument denominators, times
117                    the total of `weights`. This is like rolling all of the
118                    possible dice, and then selecting a result.
119                * 'lcm' (default): LCM of the individual argument denominators,
120                    times the total of `weights`. This is like rolling `weights`
121                    first, then selecting an argument to roll.
122                * 'lcm_weighted': LCM of the individual (argument denominators
123                    times corresponding element of `weights`). This is like
124                    rolling the above, but the specific weight rolled is used
125                    to help determine the result of the selected argument.
126                * 'reduce': The final weights are divided by their GCD.
127        Raises:
128            `ValueError`: `None` is not a valid outcome for a die.
129        """
130        if isinstance(outcomes, Die):
131            if times == 1:
132                return outcomes
133            else:
134                outcomes = outcomes._data
135
136        outcomes, times = icepool.creation_args.itemize(outcomes, times)
137
138        if len(outcomes) == 1 and times[0] == 1 and isinstance(
139                outcomes[0], Die):
140            return outcomes[0]
141
142        self = super(Die, cls).__new__(cls)
143        self._data = icepool.creation_args.expand_args_for_die(
144            outcomes, times, denominator_method=denominator_method)
145        return self

Constructor for a die.

Don't confuse this with d():

  • Die([6]): A die that always rolls the int 6.
  • d(6): A d6.

Also, don't confuse this with Pool():

  • Die([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]): A d6.
  • Pool([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]): A pool of six dice that always rolls one of each number.

Here are some different ways of constructing a d6:

  • Just import it: from icepool import d6
  • Use the d() function: icepool.d(6)
  • Use a d6 that you already have: Die(d6)
  • Mix a d3 and a d3+3: Die(d3, d3+3)
  • Use a dict: Die({1:1, 2:1, 3:1, 4:1, 5:1, 6:1})
  • Give the faces as args: Die(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6)

All weights must be non-negative, though they can be zero.

Args

  • outcomes: The outcomes of the die. This can be one of the following:

    • A dict mapping outcomes to weights.
    • A sequence of outcomes. Each element will have the same total weight.

    Each outcome may be one of the following:

    • A Die. The outcomes of the die will be "flattened" into the result; a Die will never contain a Die as an outcome.
    • A dict-like that maps outcomes to weights. The outcomes of the dict-like will be "flattened" into the result. This option will be taken in preference to treating the dict-like itself as an outcome even if the dict-like itself is hashable and totally orderable.

    • A tuple of outcomes. Operators on dice with tuple outcomes are performed element-wise. See Die.unary_op and Die.binary_op for details.

      Any tuple elements that are dice or dicts will expand the tuple according to their independent joint distribution. For example, (d6, d6) will expand to 36 ordered tuples with weight 1 each. Use this carefully since it may create a large number of outcomes.

    • icepool.Reroll, which will drop itself and the corresponding element of times from consideration. If inside a tuple, the tuple will be dropped.
    • Anything else, including non-tuple sequences, will be treated as a single outcome. Each outcome must be hashable, and the set of outcomes must be totally orderable (after expansion). The same outcome can appear multiple times, in which case the corresponding weights will be accumulated.
  • times: Multiplies the weight of each element of outcomes. times can either be a sequence of the same length as outcomes or a single int to apply to all elements of outcomes.
  • denominator_method: How to determine the denominator of the result if the arguments themselves contain weights. This is also used for dict-like arguments. From greatest to least:
    • 'prod': Product of the individual argument denominators, times the total of weights. This is like rolling all of the possible dice, and then selecting a result.
    • 'lcm' (default): LCM of the individual argument denominators, times the total of weights. This is like rolling weights first, then selecting an argument to roll.
    • 'lcm_weighted': LCM of the individual (argument denominators times corresponding element of weights). This is like rolling the above, but the specific weight rolled is used to help determine the result of the selected argument.
    • 'reduce': The final weights are divided by their GCD.
Raises
  • ValueError: None is not a valid outcome for a die.
def unary_op(self, op: Callable, *args, **kwargs) -> icepool.Die: 
147    def unary_op(self, op: Callable, *args, **kwargs) -> 'Die':
148        """Performs the unary operation on the outcomes.
149
150        Operations on tuples are performed elementwise recursively. If you need
151        some other specific behavior, use your own outcome class, or use `sub()`
152        rather than an operator.
153
154        This is used for the standard unary operators
155        `-, +, abs, ~, round, trunc, floor, ceil`
156        as well as the additional methods
157        `zero, bool`.
158
159        This is NOT used for the `[]` operator, which is NOT performed
160        element-wise.
161
162        Returns:
163            A die representing the result.
164
165        Raises:
166            ValueError if tuples are of mismatched length.
167        """
168        data: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
169        for outcome, weight in self.items():
170            new_outcome = unary_elementwise(outcome, op, *args, **kwargs)
171            data[new_outcome] += weight
172        return icepool.Die(data)

Performs the unary operation on the outcomes.

Operations on tuples are performed elementwise recursively. If you need some other specific behavior, use your own outcome class, or use sub() rather than an operator.

This is used for the standard unary operators -, +, abs, ~, round, trunc, floor, ceil as well as the additional methods zero, bool.

This is NOT used for the [] operator, which is NOT performed element-wise.

Returns

A die representing the result.

Raises
  • ValueError if tuples are of mismatched length.
def unary_op_non_elementwise(self, op: Callable, *args, **kwargs) -> icepool.Die:

175        """As `unary_op()`, but not elementwise.

177        This is used for the `[]` operator.
178        """

def binary_op( self, other: icepool.Die, op: Callable, *args, **kwargs) -> icepool.Die: 
185    def binary_op(self, other: 'Die', op: Callable, *args, **kwargs) -> 'Die':
186        """Performs the operation on pairs of outcomes.
187
188        Operations on tuples are performed elementwise recursively. If you need
189        some other specific behavior, use your own outcome class, or use `sub()`
190        rather than an operator.
191
192        By the time this is called, the other operand has already been
193        converted to a die.
194
195        This is used for the standard binary operators
196        `+, -, *, /, //, %, **, <<, >>, &, |, ^, <, <=, >=, >, ==, !=`,
197        as well as the additional method `cmp`.
198        Note that `*` multiplies outcomes directly;
199        it is not the same as `@`, which rolls the right side multiple times,
200        or `d()`, which creates a standard die.
201
202        `==` and `!=` additionally set the truth value of the die according to
203        whether the dice themselves are the same or not.
204
205        The `@` operator does NOT use this method directly.
206        It rolls the left die, which must have integer outcomes,
207        then rolls the right die that many times and sums the outcomes.
208        Only the sum is performed element-wise.
209
210        Returns:
211            A die representing the result.
212
213        Raises:
214            `ValueError` if tuples are of mismatched length within one of the
215                dice or between the dice.
216        """
217        data: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
218        for (outcome_self, weight_self), (outcome_other,
219                                          weight_other) in itertools.product(
220                                              self.items(), other.items()):
221            new_outcome = binary_elementwise(outcome_self, outcome_other, op,
222                                             *args, **kwargs)
223            data[new_outcome] += weight_self * weight_other
224        return icepool.Die(data)

Performs the operation on pairs of outcomes.

Operations on tuples are performed elementwise recursively. If you need some other specific behavior, use your own outcome class, or use sub() rather than an operator.

By the time this is called, the other operand has already been converted to a die.

This is used for the standard binary operators +, -, *, /, //, %, **, <<, >>, &, |, ^, <, <=, >=, >, ==, !=, as well as the additional method cmp. Note that * multiplies outcomes directly; it is not the same as @, which rolls the right side multiple times, or d(), which creates a standard die.

== and != additionally set the truth value of the die according to whether the dice themselves are the same or not.

The @ operator does NOT use this method directly. It rolls the left die, which must have integer outcomes, then rolls the right die that many times and sums the outcomes. Only the sum is performed element-wise.

Returns

A die representing the result.

Raises
  • ValueError if tuples are of mismatched length within one of the dice or between the dice.

410        """Kolmogorov–Smirnov stat. The maximum absolute difference between CDFs. """
411        a, b = icepool.align(self, other)
412        return max(abs(a - b) for a, b in zip(a.cdf(), b.cdf()))

def ppf_left(self, n: int, d: int = 100) 
440    def ppf_left(self, n: int, d: int = 100):
441        """Returns a quantile, `n / d` of the way through the cdf.
442
443        If the result lies between two outcomes, returns the lower of the two.
444        """
445        index = bisect.bisect_left(self.cweights(),
446                                   (n * self.denominator() + d - 1) // d)
447        if index >= self.num_outcomes():
448            return self.max_outcome()
449        return self.outcomes()[index]

Returns a quantile, n / d of the way through the cdf.

If the result lies between two outcomes, returns the lower of the two.

def ppf_right(self, n: int, d: int = 100) 
451    def ppf_right(self, n: int, d: int = 100):
452        """Returns a quantile, `n / d` of the way through the cdf.
453
454        If the result lies between two outcomes, returns the higher of the two.
455        """
456        index = bisect.bisect_right(self.cweights(),
457                                    n * self.denominator() // d)
458        if index >= self.num_outcomes():
459            return self.max_outcome()
460        return self.outcomes()[index]

462    def ppf(self, n: int, d: int = 100):

def mean(self)

def variance(self) 
475    def variance(self):
476        mean = self.mean()
477        mean_of_squares = sum(
478            p * outcome**2 for outcome, p in zip(self.outcomes(), self.pmf()))
479        return mean_of_squares - mean * mean
def standard_deviation(self) 
481    def standard_deviation(self):
482        return math.sqrt(self.variance())
def sd(self) 
481    def standard_deviation(self):
482        return math.sqrt(self.variance())
def standardized_moment(self, k: int) 
486    def standardized_moment(self, k: int):
487        sd = self.standard_deviation()
488        mean = self.mean()
489        ev = sum(p * (outcome - mean)**k
490                 for outcome, p in zip(self.outcomes(), self.pmf()))
491        return ev / (sd**k)
def skewness(self) 
493    def skewness(self):
494        return self.standardized_moment(3.0)
def excess_kurtosis(self) 
496    def excess_kurtosis(self):
497        return self.standardized_moment(4.0) - 3.0
def covariance(self, i: int, j: int) 
501    def covariance(self, i: int, j: int):
502        mean_i = self[i].mean()
503        mean_j = self[j].mean()
504        return sum((outcome[i] - mean_i) * (outcome[j] - mean_j) * weight
505                   for outcome, weight in self.items()) / self.denominator()
def correlation(self, i: int, j: int) 
507    def correlation(self, i: int, j: int):
508        sd_i = self[i].standard_deviation()
509        sd_j = self[j].standard_deviation()
510        return self.covariance(i, j) / (sd_i * sd_j)

def scale_weights(self, scale: int) -> icepool.Die: 
518    def scale_weights(self, scale: int) -> 'Die':
519        """Multiplies all weights by a constant. """
520        if scale < 0:
521            raise ValueError('Weights cannot be scaled by a negative number.')
522        if scale == 1:
523            return self

def reroll( self, outcomes: Union[Callable[..., bool], collections.abc.Container, NoneType] = None, *, max_depth: int | None = None, star: int = 0) -> icepool.Die: 
557    def reroll(self,
558               outcomes: Callable[..., bool] | Container | None = None,
559               *,
560               max_depth: int | None = None,
561               star: int = 0) -> 'Die':
562        """Rerolls the given outcomes.
563
564        Args:
565            outcomes: Selects which outcomes to reroll. Options:
566                * A callable that takes an outcome and returns `True` if it
567                    should be rerolled.
568                * A container of outcomes to reroll.
569                * If not provided, the min outcome will be rerolled.
570            max_depth: The maximum number of times to reroll.
571                If omitted, rerolls an unlimited number of times.
572            star: If set to `True` or 1, outcomes will be unpacked as
573                `*outcome` before giving it to the `outcomes` function.
574                If `outcomes` is not a callable, this has no effect.
575
576        Returns:
577            A die representing the reroll.
578            If the reroll would never terminate, the result has no outcomes.
579        """
580        if outcomes is None:
581            outcomes = {self.min_outcome()}
582        elif callable(outcomes):
583            if star:
584                outcomes = {
585                    outcome for outcome in self.outcomes() if outcomes(*outcome)
586                }
587            else:
588                outcomes = {
589                    outcome for outcome in self.outcomes() if outcomes(outcome)
590                }
591
592        if max_depth is None:
593            data = {
594                outcome: weight
595                for outcome, weight in self.items()
596                if outcome not in outcomes
597            }
598        else:
599            total_reroll_weight = sum(
600                weight for outcome, weight in self.items()
601                if outcome in outcomes)
602            rerollable_factor = total_reroll_weight**max_depth
603            stop_factor = (self.denominator()**max_depth +
604                           total_reroll_weight**max_depth)
605            data = {
606                outcome:
607                (rerollable_factor *
608                 weight if outcome in outcomes else stop_factor * weight)
609                for outcome, weight in self.items()
610            }
611        return icepool.Die(data)

Rerolls the given outcomes.

Args
  • outcomes: Selects which outcomes to reroll. Options:
    • A callable that takes an outcome and returns True if it should be rerolled.
    • A container of outcomes to reroll.
    • If not provided, the min outcome will be rerolled.
  • max_depth: The maximum number of times to reroll. If omitted, rerolls an unlimited number of times.
  • star: If set to True or 1, outcomes will be unpacked as *outcome before giving it to the outcomes function. If outcomes is not a callable, this has no effect.
Returns

A die representing the reroll. If the reroll would never terminate, the result has no outcomes.

def reroll_until( self, outcomes: Union[Callable[..., bool], collections.abc.Container], *, max_depth: int | None = None, star: int = 0) -> icepool.Die: 
613    def reroll_until(self,
614                     outcomes: Callable[..., bool] | Container,
615                     *,
616                     max_depth: int | None = None,
617                     star: int = 0) -> 'Die':
618        """Rerolls until getting one of the given outcomes.
619
620        Essentially the complement of `reroll()`.
621
622        Args:
623            outcomes: Selects which outcomes to reroll until. Options:
624                * A callable that takes an outcome and returns `True` if it
625                    should be accepted.
626                * A container of outcomes to reroll until.
627            max_depth: The maximum number of times to reroll.
628                If omitted, rerolls an unlimited number of times.
629            star: If set to `True` or 1, outcomes will be unpacked as
630                `*outcome` before giving it to the `outcomes` function.
631                If `outcomes` is not a callable, this has no effect.
632
633        Returns:
634            A die representing the reroll.
635            If the reroll would never terminate, the result has no outcomes.
636        """
637        if callable(outcomes):
638            if star:
639                not_outcomes = {
640                    outcome for outcome in self.outcomes()
641                    if not outcomes(*outcome)
642                }
643            else:
644                not_outcomes = {
645                    outcome for outcome in self.outcomes()
646                    if not outcomes(outcome)
647                }
648        else:
649            not_outcomes = {
650                not_outcome for not_outcome in self.outcomes()
651                if not_outcome not in outcomes
652            }
653        return self.reroll(not_outcomes, max_depth=max_depth)

Rerolls until getting one of the given outcomes.

Essentially the complement of reroll().

Args
  • outcomes: Selects which outcomes to reroll until. Options:
    • A callable that takes an outcome and returns True if it should be accepted.
    • A container of outcomes to reroll until.
  • max_depth: The maximum number of times to reroll. If omitted, rerolls an unlimited number of times.
  • star: If set to True or 1, outcomes will be unpacked as *outcome before giving it to the outcomes function. If outcomes is not a callable, this has no effect.
Returns

A die representing the reroll. If the reroll would never terminate, the result has no outcomes.

def truncate(self, min_outcome=None, max_outcome=None) -> icepool.Die: 
655    def truncate(self, min_outcome=None, max_outcome=None) -> 'Die':
656        """Truncates the outcomes of this die to the given range.
657
658        The endpoints are included in the result if applicable.
659        If one of the arguments is not provided, that side will not be truncated.
660
661        This effectively rerolls outcomes outside the given range.
662        If instead you want to replace those outcomes with the nearest endpoint,
663        use `clip()`.
664
665        Not to be confused with `trunc(die)`, which performs integer truncation
666        on each outcome.
667        """
668        if min_outcome is not None:
669            start = bisect.bisect_left(self.outcomes(), min_outcome)
670        else:
671            start = None
672        if max_outcome is not None:
673            stop = bisect.bisect_right(self.outcomes(), max_outcome)
674        else:
675            stop = None
676        data = {k: v for k, v in self.items()[start:stop]}
677        return icepool.Die(data)

Truncates the outcomes of this die to the given range.

The endpoints are included in the result if applicable. If one of the arguments is not provided, that side will not be truncated.

This effectively rerolls outcomes outside the given range. If instead you want to replace those outcomes with the nearest endpoint, use clip().

Not to be confused with trunc(die), which performs integer truncation on each outcome.

def clip(self, min_outcome=None, max_outcome=None) -> icepool.Die: 
679    def clip(self, min_outcome=None, max_outcome=None) -> 'Die':
680        """Clips the outcomes of this die to the given values.
681
682        The endpoints are included in the result if applicable.
683        If one of the arguments is not provided, that side will not be clipped.
684
685        This is not the same as rerolling outcomes beyond this range;
686        the outcome is simply adjusted to fit within the range.
687        This will typically cause some weight to bunch up at the endpoint.
688        If you want to reroll outcomes beyond this range, use `truncate()`.
689        """
690        data: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
691        for outcome, weight in self.items():
692            if min_outcome is not None and outcome <= min_outcome:
693                data[min_outcome] += weight
694            elif max_outcome is not None and outcome >= max_outcome:
695                data[max_outcome] += weight
696            else:
697                data[outcome] += weight
698        return icepool.Die(data)

Clips the outcomes of this die to the given values.

The endpoints are included in the result if applicable. If one of the arguments is not provided, that side will not be clipped.

This is not the same as rerolling outcomes beyond this range; the outcome is simply adjusted to fit within the range. This will typically cause some weight to bunch up at the endpoint. If you want to reroll outcomes beyond this range, use truncate().
