def sub( self, repl: Union[collections.abc.Mapping, Callable[[Any], Any], collections.abc.Sequence], /, *extra_args, max_depth: int | None = 1, star: int = 0, denominator_method: str = 'lcm') -> icepool.Die: 
760    def sub(self,
761            repl: Mapping | Callable[[Any], Any] | Sequence,
762            /,
763            *extra_args,
764            max_depth: int | None = 1,
765            star: int = 0,
766            denominator_method: str = 'lcm') -> 'Die':
767        """Changes outcomes of the die to other outcomes.
768
769        You can think of this as `sub`stituting outcomes of this die for other
770        outcomes or dice. Or, as executing a `sub`routine based on the roll of
771        this die.
772
773        Args:
774            repl: One of the following:
775                * A map from old outcomes to new outcomes.
776                    Unmapped old outcomes stay the same.
777                * A callable mapping old outcomes to new outcomes.
778                * A sequence specifying new outcomes in order.
779                The new outcomes may be dice rather than just single outcomes.
780                The special value `icepool.Reroll` will reroll that old outcome.
781            *extra_args: These will be supplied to `repl` as extra positional
782                arguments after the outcome argument(s). `extra_args` can only
783                be supplied if `repl` is callable.
784            max_depth: `sub()` will be repeated with the same argument on the
785                result this many times. If set to `None`, this will repeat until
786                a fixed point is reached.
787            star: If set to `True` or 1, outcomes will be unpacked as
788                `*outcome` before giving it to the `repl` function. If `repl`
789                is not a callable, this has no effect.
790            denominator_method: As `icepool.Die()`.
791
792        Returns:
793            The relabeled die.
794
795        Raises:
796            `ValueError` if `extra_args` are supplied with a non-callable `repl`.
797        """
798        if extra_args and not callable(repl):
799            raise ValueError(
800                'Extra positional arguments are only valid if repl is callable.'
801            )
802
803        if max_depth == 0:
804            return self
805        elif max_depth == 1:
806            if isinstance(repl, Mapping):
807                final_repl = [(repl[outcome] if outcome in repl else outcome)
808                              for outcome in self.outcomes()]
809            elif callable(repl):
810                if star:
811                    final_repl = [
812                        repl(*outcome, *extra_args)
813                        for outcome in self.outcomes()
814                    ]
815                else:
816                    final_repl = [
817                        repl(outcome, *extra_args)
818                        for outcome in self.outcomes()
819                    ]
820            else:
821                final_repl = list(repl)
822
823            return icepool.Die(final_repl,
824                               self.weights(),
825                               denominator_method=denominator_method)
826        elif max_depth is not None:
827            next = self.sub(repl,
828                            max_depth=1,
829                            denominator_method=denominator_method)
830            return next.sub(repl,
831                            max_depth=max_depth - 1,
832                            denominator_method=denominator_method)
833        else:
834            # Seek fixed point.
835            next = self.sub(repl,
836                            max_depth=1,
837                            denominator_method=denominator_method)
838            if self.reduce_weights().equals(next.reduce_weights()):
839                return self
840            else:
841                return next.sub(repl,
842                                max_depth=None,
843                                denominator_method=denominator_method)

Changes outcomes of the die to other outcomes.

You can think of this as substituting outcomes of this die for other outcomes or dice. Or, as executing a subroutine based on the roll of this die.

Args
  • repl: One of the following:
    • A map from old outcomes to new outcomes. Unmapped old outcomes stay the same.
    • A callable mapping old outcomes to new outcomes.
    • A sequence specifying new outcomes in order. The new outcomes may be dice rather than just single outcomes. The special value icepool.Reroll will reroll that old outcome.
  • *extra_args: These will be supplied to repl as extra positional arguments after the outcome argument(s). extra_args can only be supplied if repl is callable.
  • max_depth: sub() will be repeated with the same argument on the result this many times. If set to None, this will repeat until a fixed point is reached.
  • star: If set to True or 1, outcomes will be unpacked as *outcome before giving it to the repl function. If repl is not a callable, this has no effect.
  • denominator_method: As icepool.Die().
Returns

The relabeled die.

Raises
  • ValueError if extra_args are supplied with a non-callable repl.
def explode( self, outcomes: Union[Callable[..., bool], collections.abc.Container, NoneType] = None, *, max_depth: int = 9, star: int = 0) -> icepool.Die: 
845    def explode(self,
846                outcomes: Container | Callable[..., bool] | None = None,
847                *,
848                max_depth: int = 9,
849                star: int = 0) -> 'Die':
850        """Causes outcomes to be rolled again and added to the total.
851
852        Args:
853            outcomes: Which outcomes to explode. Options:
854                * An container of outcomes to explode.
855                * A callable that takes an outcome and returns `True` if it
856                    should be exploded.
857                * If not supplied, the max outcome will explode.
858            max_depth: The maximum number of additional dice to roll.
859                If not supplied, a default value will be used.
860            star: If set to `True` or 1, outcomes will be unpacked as
861                `*outcome` before giving it to the `outcomes` function.
862                If `outcomes` is not a callable, this has no effect.
863        """
864        if outcomes is None:
865            outcomes = {self.max_outcome()}
866        elif callable(outcomes):
867            if star:
868                outcomes = {
869                    outcome for outcome in self.outcomes() if outcomes(*outcome)
870                }
871            else:
872                outcomes = {
873                    outcome for outcome in self.outcomes() if outcomes(outcome)
874                }
875        else:
876            if not outcomes:
877                return self
878
879        if max_depth < 0:
880            raise ValueError('max_depth cannot be negative.')
881        elif max_depth == 0:
882            return self
883
884        tail_die = self.explode(outcomes=outcomes, max_depth=max_depth - 1)
885
886        def sub_func(outcome):
887            if outcome in outcomes:
888                return outcome + tail_die
889            else:
890                return outcome
891
892        return self.sub(sub_func, denominator_method='lcm')

Causes outcomes to be rolled again and added to the total.

Args
  • outcomes: Which outcomes to explode. Options:
    • An container of outcomes to explode.
    • A callable that takes an outcome and returns True if it should be exploded.
    • If not supplied, the max outcome will explode.
  • max_depth: The maximum number of additional dice to roll. If not supplied, a default value will be used.
  • star: If set to True or 1, outcomes will be unpacked as *outcome before giving it to the outcomes function. If outcomes is not a callable, this has no effect.
def if_else( self, outcome_if_true, outcome_if_false, /, *, denominator_method: str = 'lcm') -> icepool.Die: 
894    def if_else(self,
895                outcome_if_true,
896                outcome_if_false,
897                /,
898                *,
899                denominator_method: str = 'lcm') -> 'Die':
900        """Ternary conditional operator.
901

def keep_highest( self, num_dice: int, num_keep: int = 1, num_drop: int = 0) -> icepool.Die: 
969    def keep_highest(self,
970                     num_dice: int,
971                     num_keep: int = 1,
972                     num_drop: int = 0) -> 'Die':
973        """Roll several of this die and sum the sorted results from the highest.
974

def equals(self, other, *, reduce=False) 
1332    def equals(self, other, *, reduce=False):
1333        """Returns `True` iff both dice have the same outcomes and weights.
1334
1335        Truth value does NOT matter.
1336
1337        If one die has a zero-weight outcome and the other die does not contain
1338        that outcome, they are treated as unequal by this function.
1339
1340        The `==` and `!=` operators have a dual purpose; they return a die
1341        with a truth value determined by this method.
1342        Only dice returned by these methods have a truth value. The data of
1343        these dice is lazily evaluated since the caller may only be interested
1344        in the truth value.
1345
1346        Args:
1347            reduce: If `True`, the dice will be reduced before comparing.
1348                Otherwise, e.g. a 2:2 coin is not `equals()` to a 1:1 coin.
1349        """
1350        try:
1351            other = icepool.Die([other])
1352        except ValueError:
1353            return False
1354
1355        if reduce:
1356            return self.reduce_weights().key_tuple() == other.reduce_weights(
1357            ).key_tuple()
1358        else:
1359            return self.key_tuple() == other.key_tuple()

Returns True iff both dice have the same outcomes and weights.

Truth value does NOT matter.

If one die has a zero-weight outcome and the other die does not contain that outcome, they are treated as unequal by this function.

The == and != operators have a dual purpose; they return a die with a truth value determined by this method. Only dice returned by these methods have a truth value. The data of these dice is lazily evaluated since the caller may only be interested in the truth value.

  • reduce: If True, the dice will be reduced before comparing. Otherwise, e.g. a 2:2 coin is not equals() to a 1:1 coin.
def format(self, format_spec: str, **kwargs) -> str: 
1371    def format(self, format_spec: str, **kwargs) -> str:
1372        """Formats this die as a string.
1373
1374        `format_spec` should start with the output format,
1375        which is either `md` (Markdown) or `csv` (comma-separated values),
1376        followed by a ':' character.
1377
1378        After this, zero or more columns should follow. Options are:
1379
1380        * `o`: Outcomes.
1381        * `*o`: Outcomes, unpacked if applicable.
1382        * `w==`, `w<=`, `w>=`: Weights ==, <=, or >= each outcome.
1383        * `%==`, `%<=`, `%>=`: Chance (%) ==, <=, or >= each outcome.
1384
1385        Columns may optionally be separated using ` ` (space) or `|` characters.
1386
1387        The default is `'md:*o|w==|%=='`, with the weight column being omitted
1388        if any weight exceeds 10**30.
1389        """
1390        if len(format_spec) == 0:
1391            format_spec = 'md:*o'
1392            if not self.is_empty() and self.modal_weight() < 10**30:
1393                format_spec += 'w=='
1394            format_spec += '%=='
1395
1396        format_spec = format_spec.replace('|', '')
1397
1398        output_format, format_spec = format_spec.split(':')
1399        if output_format == 'md':
1400            return icepool.die.format.markdown(self, format_spec)
1401        elif output_format == 'csv':
1402            return icepool.die.format.csv(self, format_spec, **kwargs)
1403        else:
1404            raise ValueError(f"Unsupported output format '{output_format}'")

Formats this die as a string.

format_spec should start with the output format, which is either md (Markdown) or csv (comma-separated values), followed by a ':' character.

After this, zero or more columns should follow. Options are:

  • o: Outcomes.
  • *o: Outcomes, unpacked if applicable.
  • w==, w<=, w>=: Weights ==, <=, or >= each outcome.
  • %==, %<=, %>=: Chance (%) ==, <=, or >= each outcome.

Columns may optionally be separated using (space) or | characters.

The default is 'md:*o|w==|%==', with the weight column being omitted if any weight exceeds 10**30.

def from_cweights( outcomes: collections.abc.Sequence, cweights: collections.abc.Sequence[int]) -> icepool.Die: 
61def from_cweights(outcomes: Sequence, cweights: Sequence[int]) -> 'icepool.Die':
62    """Constructs a die from cumulative weights. """
63    prev = 0
64    d = {}
65    for outcome, weight in zip(outcomes, cweights):
66        d[outcome] = weight - prev
67        prev = weight
68    return icepool.Die(d)

Constructs a die from cumulative weights.

def from_sweights( outcomes: collections.abc.Sequence, sweights: collections.abc.Sequence[int]) -> icepool.Die: 
71def from_sweights(outcomes: Sequence, sweights: Sequence[int]) -> 'icepool.Die':
72    """Constructs a die from survival weights. """
73    prev = 0
74    d = {}
75    for outcome, weight in zip(reversed(outcomes), reversed(tuple(sweights))):
76        d[outcome] = weight - prev
77        prev = weight
78    return icepool.Die(d)

Constructs a die from survival weights.

def from_rv( rv, outcomes: collections.abc.Sequence[int | float], denominator: int, **kwargs) 
 81def from_rv(rv, outcomes: Sequence[int | float], denominator: int, **kwargs):
 82    """Constructs a die from a rv object (as `scipy.stats`).
 83    Args:
 84        rv: A rv object (as `scipy.stats`).
 85        outcomes: An iterable of `int`s or `float`s that will be the outcomes
 86            of the resulting die.
 87            If the distribution is discrete, outcomes must be `int`s.
 88        denominator: The denominator of the resulting die will be set to this.
 89        **kwargs: These will be provided to `rv.cdf()`.
 90    """
 91    if hasattr(rv, 'pdf'):
 92        # Continuous distributions use midpoints.
 93        midpoints = [(a + b) / 2 for a, b in zip(outcomes[:-1], outcomes[1:])]
 94        cdf = rv.cdf(midpoints, **kwargs)
 95        cweights = tuple(
 96            int(round(x * denominator)) for x in cdf) + (denominator,)
 97    else:
 98        cdf = rv.cdf(outcomes, **kwargs)
 99        cweights = tuple(int(round(x * denominator)) for x in cdf)
100    return from_cweights(outcomes, cweights)

Constructs a die from a rv object (as scipy.stats).

Args
  • rv: A rv object (as scipy.stats).
  • outcomes: An iterable of ints or floats that will be the outcomes of the resulting die. If the distribution is discrete, outcomes must be ints.
  • denominator: The denominator of the resulting die will be set to this.
  • **kwargs: These will be provided to rv.cdf().

def reduce(func: Callable[[Any, Any], Any], dice, *, initial=None) 
146def reduce(func: Callable[[Any, Any], Any], dice, *, initial=None):
147    """Applies a function of two arguments cumulatively to a sequence of dice.
148
149    Analogous to
150    [`functools.reduce()`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functools.html#functools.reduce).
151
152    The function is applied non-elementwise to tuple outcomes.
153
154    Args:
155        func: The function to apply. The function should take two arguments,
156            which are an outcome from each of two dice.
157        dice: A sequence of dice to apply the function to, from left to right.
158        initial: If provided, this will be placed at the front of the sequence
159            of dice.
160    """
161    # Conversion to dice is not necessary since apply() takes care of that.
162    iter_dice = iter(dice)
163    if initial is not None:
164        result = initial
165    else:
166        result = next(iter_dice)
167    for die in iter_dice:
168        result = apply(func, result, die)
169    return result

Applies a function of two arguments cumulatively to a sequence of dice.

Analogous to functools.reduce().

The function is applied non-elementwise to tuple outcomes.

Args
  • func: The function to apply. The function should take two arguments, which are an outcome from each of two dice.
  • dice: A sequence of dice to apply the function to, from left to right.
  • initial: If provided, this will be placed at the front of the sequence of dice.
def accumulate(func: Callable[[Any, Any], Any], dice, *, initial=None) 
172def accumulate(func: Callable[[Any, Any], Any], dice, *, initial=None):
173    """Applies a function of two arguments cumulatively to a sequence of dice, yielding each result in turn.
174
175    Analogous to
176    [`itertools.accumulate()`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/itertools.html#itertools.accumulate)
177    , though with no default function and
178    the same parameter order as `reduce()`.
179
180    The number of results is equal to the number of elements of `dice`, with
181    one additional element if `initial` is provided.
182
183    The function is applied non-elementwise to tuple outcomes.
184
185    Args:
186        func: The function to apply. The function should take two arguments,
187            which are an outcome from each of two dice.
188        dice: A sequence of dice to apply the function to, from left to right.
189        initial: If provided, this will be placed at the front of the sequence
190            of dice.
191    """
192    # Conversion to dice is not necessary since apply() takes care of that.
193    iter_dice = iter(dice)
194    if initial is not None:
195        result = initial
196    else:
197        try:
198            result = next(iter_dice)
199        except StopIteration:
200            return
201    yield result
202    for die in iter_dice:
203        result = apply(func, result, die)
204        yield result

Applies a function of two arguments cumulatively to a sequence of dice, yielding each result in turn.

Analogous to itertools.accumulate() , though with no default function and the same parameter order as reduce().

The number of results is equal to the number of elements of dice, with one additional element if initial is provided.

The function is applied non-elementwise to tuple outcomes.

Args
  • func: The function to apply. The function should take two arguments, which are an outcome from each of two dice.
  • dice: A sequence of dice to apply the function to, from left to right.
  • initial: If provided, this will be placed at the front of the sequence of dice.
def apply(func: Callable, *dice) -> icepool.Die: 
207def apply(func: Callable, *dice) -> 'icepool.Die':
208    """Applies `func(outcome_of_die_0, outcome_of_die_1, ...)` for all possible outcomes of the dice.
209
210    Example: `apply(lambda a, b: a + b, d6, d6)` is the same as d6 + d6.
211
212    `apply()` is flexible but not very efficient for more than two dice.
213    Instead of using more than two arguments:
214
215    * If the problem is easy to solve by considering one additional die at a
216        time, try using `reduce()` instead.
217    * If the problem is easy to solve by considering how many dice rolled each
218        outcome, one outcome at a time, try using
219        `icepool.Pool` and `icepool.EvalPool`.
220    * If the order in which the dice are rolled is not important, you can use
221        `apply_sorted()`. This is less efficient than either of the above two,
222        but is still more efficient than `apply()`.
223
224    Args:
225        func: A function that takes one argument per input die and returns an
226            argument to `Die()`.
227        *dice: Any number of dice (or objects convertible to dice).
228            `func` will be called with all possible joint outcomes of `dice`,
229            with one argument per die.
230
231    Returns:
232        A die constructed from the outputs of `func` and the product of the
233        weights of the dice.
234    """
235    if len(dice) == 0:
236        return icepool.Die([func()])
237    dice = tuple(icepool.Die([die]) for die in dice)
238    final_outcomes = []
239    final_weights = []
240    for t in itertools.product(*(die.items() for die in dice)):
241        outcomes, weights = zip(*t)
242        final_outcome = func(*outcomes)
243        final_weight = math.prod(weights)
244        if final_outcome is not icepool.Reroll:
245            final_outcomes.append(final_outcome)
246            final_weights.append(final_weight)
247
248    return icepool.Die(final_outcomes, final_weights)

Applies func(outcome_of_die_0, outcome_of_die_1, ...) for all possible outcomes of the dice.

Example: apply(lambda a, b: a + b, d6, d6) is the same as d6 + d6.

apply() is flexible but not very efficient for more than two dice. Instead of using more than two arguments:

  • If the problem is easy to solve by considering one additional die at a time, try using reduce() instead.
  • If the problem is easy to solve by considering how many dice rolled each outcome, one outcome at a time, try using icepool.Pool and icepool.EvalPool.
  • If the order in which the dice are rolled is not important, you can use apply_sorted(). This is less efficient than either of the above two, but is still more efficient than apply().
Args
  • func: A function that takes one argument per input die and returns an argument to Die().
  • *dice: Any number of dice (or objects convertible to dice). func will be called with all possible joint outcomes of dice, with one argument per die.
Returns

A die constructed from the outputs of func and the product of the weights of the dice.

def apply_sorted(func: Callable, *dice) -> icepool.Die: 
251def apply_sorted(func: Callable, *dice) -> 'icepool.Die':
252    """Applies `func(lowest_outcome, next_lowest_outcome...)` for all possible sorted outcomes of the dice.
253
254    This is more efficient than `apply` but still not very efficient.
255    Use `EvalPool` instead if at all possible.
256
257    Args:
258        func: A function that takes one argument per input die and returns an
259            argument to `Die()`.
260        *dice: Any number of dice (or objects convertible to dice).
261            `func` will be called with all possible sorted outcomes of `dice`,
262            with one argument per die. All outcomes must be totally orderable.
263
264    Returns:
265        A die constructed from the outputs of `func` and the weight of rolling
266        the corresponding sorted outcomes.
267    """
268    pool = icepool.Pool(dice)
269    return icepool.enumerate_gen(pool).sub(func, star=1)

Applies func(lowest_outcome, next_lowest_outcome...) for all possible sorted outcomes of the dice.

This is more efficient than apply but still not very efficient. Use EvalPool instead if at all possible.

Args
  • func: A function that takes one argument per input die and returns an argument to Die().
  • *dice: Any number of dice (or objects convertible to dice). func will be called with all possible sorted outcomes of dice, with one argument per die. All outcomes must be totally orderable.
Returns

A die constructed from the outputs of func and the weight of rolling the corresponding sorted outcomes.

Reroll = <SpecialValue.Reroll: 'Reroll'>

Indicates an outcome should be rerolled (with no max depth).

class OutcomeCountGen(abc.ABC): 
10class OutcomeCountGen(ABC):
11    """Abstract base class for incrementally generating (outcome, count, weight)s.
12
13    These include dice pools (`Pool`) and card decks (`Deck`).
14    """
15
16    @abstractmethod
17    def outcomes(self) -> Sequence:
18        """The set of possible outcomes, in sorted order."""
19
20    def min_outcome(self):
21        return self.outcomes()[0]
22
23    def max_outcome(self):
24        return self.outcomes()[-1]
25
26    @abstractmethod
27    def _is_resolvable(self) -> bool:
28        """Returns `True` iff the generator is capable of producing an overall outcome.
29
30        For example, a dice pool will return `False` if it contains any dice
31        with no outcomes.
32        """
33
34    @abstractmethod
35    def _pop_min(
36        self, min_outcome
37    ) -> Generator[tuple['OutcomeCountGen', int, int], None, None]:
38        """Pops the min outcome from this generator if it matches the argument.
39
40        Yields:
41            A generator with the min outcome popped.
42            The count for the min outcome.
43            The weight for this many of the min outcome appearing.
44
45            If the argument does not match the min outcome, or this generator
46            has no outcomes, only the single tuple `(self, 0, 1)` is yielded.
47        """
48
49    @abstractmethod
50    def _pop_max(
51        self, max_outcome
52    ) -> Generator[tuple['OutcomeCountGen', int, int], None, None]:
53        """Pops the max outcome from this generator if it matches the argument.
54
55        Yields:
56            A generator with the max outcome popped.
57            The count for the max outcome.
58            The weight for this many of the max outcome appearing.
59
60            If the argument does not match the max outcome, or this generator
61            has no outcomes, only the single tuple `(self, 0, 1)` is yielded.
62        """
63
64    @abstractmethod
65    def _estimate_direction_costs(self) -> tuple[int, int]:
66        """Estimates the cost of popping from the min and max sides during an evaluation.
67
68        Returns:
69            pop_min_cost: A positive `int`.
70            pop_max_cost: A positive `int`.
71        """
72
73    @abstractmethod
74    def __eq__(self, other):
75        """All `OutcomeCountGen`s must implement equality."""
76
77    @abstractmethod
78    def __hash__(self):
79        """All `OutcomeCountGen`s must be hashable."""

class Pool(icepool.OutcomeCountGen): 
 36class Pool(OutcomeCountGen):
 37    """Represents a set of unordered dice, only distinguished by the outcomes they roll.
 38
 39    This should be used in conjunction with `EvalPool` to generate a result.
 40    """
 41
 42    _post_roll_counts: tuple[int, ...]
 43    _dice: Counts
 44
 45    def __new__(cls,
 46                dice: Mapping[Any, int] | Sequence,
 47                times: Sequence[int] | int = 1) -> 'Pool':
 48        """Public constructor for a pool.
 49
 50        Evaulation is most efficient when the dice are the same or same-side
 51        truncations of each other. For example, d4, d6, d8, d10, d12 are all
 52        same-side truncations of d12.
 53
 54        Args:
 55            dice: The dice to put in the pool. This can be one of the following:
 56
 57                * A sequence of dice.
 58                * A mapping of dice and how many of that die to put in the pool.
 59
 60                All outcomes within a pool must be totally orderable.
 61            times: Multiplies the number of times each element of `dice` will
 62                be put into the pool.
 63                `times` can either be a sequence of the same length as
 64                `outcomes` or a single `int` to apply to all elements of
 65                `outcomes`.
 66
 67        """
 68        if isinstance(dice, Pool):
 69            if times == 1:
 70                return dice
 71            else:
 72                dice = dice._dice
 73
 74        dice, times = icepool.creation_args.itemize(dice, times)
 75        dice = tuple(icepool.Die([die]) for die in dice)
 76
 77        num_dices: MutableMapping['icepool.Die', int] = defaultdict(int)
 78        for die, qty in zip(dice, times):
 79            num_dices[die] += qty
 80        post_roll_counts = (1,) * sum(times)
 81        return cls._new_pool(num_dices, post_roll_counts)
 82
 83    @classmethod
 84    def _new_pool(cls, num_dices, post_roll_counts) -> 'Pool':
 85        """Creates a new pool.
 86
 87        Args:
 88            num_dices: At this point, this is a map from dice to num_dice, with
 89                no empty dice.
 90            post_roll_counts: At this point, this is a tuple with length equal to the
 91                number of dice.
 92        """
 93        sorted_num_dices = tuple(
 94            sorted(num_dices.items(), key=lambda kv: kv[0].key_tuple()))
 95        return new_pool_cached(
 96            cls,  # type: ignore
 97            sorted_num_dices,
 98            post_roll_counts)
 99
100    @cached_property
101    def _num_dice(self) -> int:
102        return sum(self._dice.values())
103
104    def num_dice(self) -> int:
105        """The number of dice in this pool."""
106        return self._num_dice
107
108    def _is_resolvable(self) -> bool:
109        return all(not die.is_empty() for die in self._dice.keys())
110
111    @cached_property
112    def _denominator(self) -> int:
113        """The product of the total dice weights in this pool."""
114        return math.prod(
115            die.denominator()**count for die, count in self._dice.items())
116
117    def denominator(self) -> int:
118        return self._denominator
119
120    @cached_property
121    def _dice_tuple(self) -> tuple['icepool.Die', ...]:
122        return sum(((die,) * count for die, count in self._dice.items()),
123                   start=())
124
125    def unique_dice(self) -> Collection['icepool.Die']:
126        return self._dice.keys()
127
128    @cached_property
129    def _outcomes(self) -> Sequence:
130        outcome_set = set(
131            itertools.chain.from_iterable(
132                die.outcomes() for die in self.unique_dice()))
133        return tuple(sorted(outcome_set))
134
135    def outcomes(self) -> Sequence:
136        """The union of outcomes among all dice in this pool."""
137        return self._outcomes
138
139    def _estimate_direction_costs(self) -> tuple[int, int]:
140        """Estimates the cost of popping from the min and max sides.
141
142        Returns:
143            pop_min_cost
144            pop_max_cost
145        """
146        return icepool.pool_cost.estimate_costs(self)
147
148    def post_roll_counts(self) -> tuple[int, ...]:
149        """The tuple indicating which dice in the pool will be counted.
150
151        The tuple has one element per die in the pool, from lowest roll to
152        highest roll.
153        """
154        return self._post_roll_counts
155
156    def set_post_roll_counts(self,
157                             post_roll_counts: int | slice | tuple[int, ...]):
158        """Returns a pool with the selected dice counted.
159
160        You can use `pool[post_roll_counts]` for the same effect as this method.
161
162        The dice are sorted in ascending order for this purpose,
163        regardless of which order the outcomes are evaluated in.
164
165        This is always an absolute selection on all `num_dice`,
166        not a relative selection on already-selected dice,
167        which would be ambiguous in the presence of multiple or negative counts.
168
169        For example, here are some ways of selecting the two highest dice out of 5:
170
171        * `pool[3:5]`
172        * `pool[3:]`
173        * `pool[-2:]`
174        * `pool[..., 1, 1]`
175
176        These will also select the two highest dice out of 5, and will also
177        resize the pool to 5 dice first:
178
179        * `pool[3::5]`
180        * `pool[3:5:5]`
181        * `pool[-2::5]`
182        * `pool[0, 0, 0, 1, 1]`
183
184        These will count the highest as a positive and the lowest as a negative:
185
186        * `pool[-1, 0, 0, 0, 1]`
187        * `pool[-1, ..., 1]`
188
189        Args:
190            An `int`. This will count only the die at the specified index (once).
191                In this case, the result will be a `Die`, not a pool.
192            A `slice`. The selected dice are counted once each.
193                If provided, the third argument resizes the pool,
194                rather than being a step; however, this is only valid if the
195                pool consists of a single type of die.
196            A sequence of one `int` for each die.
197                Each die is counted that many times, which could be multiple or
198                negative times. This may resize the pool, but only if the
199                pool consists of a single type of die.
200
201                Up to one `Ellipsis` (`...`) may be used.
202                If an `Ellipsis` is used, the size of the pool won't change.
203                Instead, the `Ellipsis` will be replaced with a number of zero
204                counts, sufficient to maintain the current size of this pool.
205                This number may be "negative" if more `int`s are provided than
206                the size of the pool. Specifically:
207
208                * If `post_roll_counts` is shorter than `num_dice`, the `Ellipsis`
209                    acts as enough zero counts to make up the difference.
210                    E.g. `pool[1, ..., 1]` on five dice would act as `pool[1, 0, 0, 0, 1]`.
211                * If `post_roll_counts` has length equal to `num_dice`, the `Ellipsis` has no effect.
212                    E.g. `pool[1, ..., 1]` on two dice would act as `pool[1, 1]`.
213                * If `post_roll_counts` is longer than `num_dice` and the `Ellipsis` is on one side,
214                    elements will be dropped from `post_roll_counts` on the side with the `Ellipsis`.
215                    E.g. `pool[..., 1, 2, 3]` on two dice would act as `pool[2, 3]`.
216                * If `post_roll_counts` is longer than `num_dice` and the `Ellipsis`
217                    is in the middle, the counts will be as the sum of two
218                    one-sided `Ellipsis`.
219                    E.g. `pool[-1, ..., 1]` acts like `[-1, ...]` plus `[..., 1]`.
220                    On a pool consisting of a single single die this would have
221                    the -1 and 1 cancel each other out.
222
223        Raises:
224            ValueError:  If `post_roll_counts` would change the size of a pool with
225                more than one type of die, or if more than one `Ellipsis`
226                is used.
227        """
228        convert_to_die = isinstance(post_roll_counts, int)
229        post_roll_counts = post_roll_counts_tuple(self.num_dice(),
230                                                  post_roll_counts)
231        if len(post_roll_counts) != self.num_dice():
232            if len(self._dice) != 1:
233                raise ValueError(
234                    'Cannot change the size of a pool unless it has exactly one type of die.'
235                )
236            dice = Counts([(self._dice.keys()[0], len(post_roll_counts))])
237            result = Pool._new_pool(dice, post_roll_counts)
238        else:
239            result = Pool._new_pool(self._dice, post_roll_counts)
240        if convert_to_die:
241            return result.eval(lambda state, outcome, count: outcome
242                               if count else state)
243        else:
244            return result
245
246    __getitem__ = set_post_roll_counts
247
248    @cached_property
249    def _min_outcome(self):
250        return min(die.min_outcome() for die in self._dice.keys())
251
252    def min_outcome(self):
253        """Returns the min outcome among all dice in this pool."""
254        return self._min_outcome
255
256    @cached_property
257    def _max_outcome(self):
258        return max(die.max_outcome() for die in self._dice.keys())
259
260    def max_outcome(self):
261        """Returns the max outcome among all dice in this pool."""
262        return self._max_outcome
263
264    def _pop_min(self,
265                 min_outcome) -> Generator[tuple['Pool', int, int], None, None]:
266        """Pops the given outcome from this pool, if it is the min outcome.
267
268        Yields:
269            popped_pool: The pool after the min outcome is popped.
270            net_count: The number of dice that rolled the min outcome, after
271                accounting for post_roll_counts.
272            net_weight: The weight of this incremental result.
273        """
274        if not self.outcomes():
275            yield self, 0, 1
276            return
277        generators = [
278            iter_die_pop_min(die, die_count, min_outcome)
279            for die, die_count in self._dice.items()
280        ]
281        skip_weight = None
282        for pop in itertools.product(*generators):
283            net_num_rolled = 0
284            result_weight = 1
285            next_dice_counts: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
286            for popped_die, num_remain, num_rolled, weight in pop:
287                if not popped_die.is_empty():
288                    next_dice_counts[popped_die] += num_remain
289                net_num_rolled += num_rolled
290                result_weight *= weight
291            if net_num_rolled == 0:
292                result_count = 0
293                popped_post_roll_counts = self.post_roll_counts()
294            else:
295                result_count = sum(self.post_roll_counts()[:net_num_rolled])
296                popped_post_roll_counts = self.post_roll_counts(
297                )[net_num_rolled:]
298            popped_pool = Pool._new_pool(next_dice_counts,
299                                         popped_post_roll_counts)
300            if not any(popped_post_roll_counts):
301                # Dump all dice in exchange for the denominator.
302                skip_weight = (skip_weight or
303                               0) + result_weight * popped_pool.denominator()
304                continue
305
306            yield popped_pool, result_count, result_weight
307
308        if skip_weight is not None:
309            yield empty_pool, sum(self.post_roll_counts()), skip_weight
310
311    def _pop_max(self,
312                 max_outcome) -> Generator[tuple['Pool', int, int], None, None]:
313        """Pops the given outcome from this pool, if it is the max outcome.
314
315        Yields:
316            popped_pool: The pool after the max outcome is popped.
317            net_count: The number of dice that rolled the max outcome, after
318                accounting for post_roll_counts.
319            net_weight: The weight of this incremental result.
320        """
321        if not self.outcomes():
322            yield self, 0, 1
323            return
324        generators = [
325            iter_die_pop_max(die, die_count, max_outcome)
326            for die, die_count in self._dice.items()
327        ]
328        skip_weight = None
329        for pop in itertools.product(*generators):
330            net_num_rolled = 0
331            result_weight = 1
332            next_dice_counts: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
333            for popped_die, num_remain, num_rolled, weight in pop:
334                if not popped_die.is_empty():
335                    next_dice_counts[popped_die] += num_remain
336                net_num_rolled += num_rolled
337                result_weight *= weight
338            if net_num_rolled == 0:
339                result_count = 0
340                popped_post_roll_counts = self.post_roll_counts()
341            else:
342                result_count = sum(self.post_roll_counts()[-net_num_rolled:])
343                popped_post_roll_counts = self.post_roll_counts(
344                )[:-net_num_rolled]
345            popped_pool = Pool._new_pool(next_dice_counts,
346                                         popped_post_roll_counts)
347            if not any(popped_post_roll_counts):
348                # Dump all dice in exchange for the denominator.
349                skip_weight = (skip_weight or
350                               0) + result_weight * popped_pool.denominator()
351                continue
352
353            yield popped_pool, result_count, result_weight
354
355        if skip_weight is not None:
356            yield empty_pool, sum(self.post_roll_counts()), skip_weight
357
358    def eval(self, eval_or_func: 'icepool.OutcomeCountEval' | Callable,
359             /) -> 'icepool.Die':
360        """Evaluates this pool using the given `OutcomeCountEval` or function.
361
362        Note that each `OutcomeCountEval` instance carries its own cache;
363        if you plan to use an evaluation multiple times,
364        you may want to explicitly create an `OutcomeCountEval` instance
365        rather than passing a function to this method directly.
366
367        Args:
368            func: This can be an `OutcomeCountEval`, in which case it evaluates
369                the pool directly. Or it can be a `OutcomeCountEval.next_state()`
370                -like function, taking in `state, outcome, *counts` and
371                returning the next state. In this case a temporary `WrapFuncEval`
372                is constructed and used to evaluate this pool.
373        """
374        if not isinstance(eval_or_func, icepool.OutcomeCountEval):
375            eval_or_func = icepool.WrapFuncEval(eval_or_func)
376        return eval_or_func.eval(self)
377
378    def sum(self) -> 'icepool.Die':
379        """Convenience method to simply sum the dice in this pool.
380
381        This uses `icepool.sum_pool`.
382
383        Returns:
384            A die representing the sum.
385        """
386        return icepool.sum_gen(self)
387
388    def lowest(self, num_keep: int = 1, num_drop: int = 0) -> 'icepool.Die':
389        """The lowest outcome or sum of the lowest outcomes in the pool.
390
391        The args override any `post_roll_counts` of this pool.
392
393        Args:
394            num_keep: The number of lowest dice will be summed.
395            num_drop: This number of lowest dice will be dropped before keeping
396                dice to be summed.
397        """
398        if num_keep < 0:
399            raise ValueError(f'num_drop={num_keep} cannot be negative.')
400        if num_drop < 0:
401            raise ValueError(f'num_drop={num_drop} cannot be negative.')
402
403        start = min(num_drop, self.num_dice())
404        stop = min(num_keep + num_drop, self.num_dice())
405        return self[start:stop].sum()  # type: ignore
406
407    def highest(self, num_keep: int = 1, num_drop: int = 0) -> 'icepool.Die':
408        """The highest outcome or sum of the highest outcomes in the pool.
409
410        The args override any `post_roll_counts` of this pool.
411
412        Args:
413            num_keep: The number of highest dice will be summed.
414            num_drop: This number of highest dice will be dropped before keeping
415                dice to be summed.
416        """
417        if num_keep < 0:
418            raise ValueError(f'num_drop={num_keep} cannot be negative.')
419        if num_drop < 0:
420            raise ValueError(f'num_drop={num_drop} cannot be negative.')
421
422        start = self.num_dice() - min(num_keep + num_drop, self.num_dice())
423        stop = self.num_dice() - min(num_drop, self.num_dice())
424        return self[start:stop].sum()  # type: ignore
425
426    def __str__(self) -> str:
427        return (
428            f'Pool of {self.num_dice()} dice with post_roll_counts={self.post_roll_counts()}\n'
429            + ''.join(f'  {repr(die)}\n' for die in self._dice_tuple))
430
431    @cached_property
432    def _key_tuple(self) -> tuple:
433        return (Pool,) + tuple(
434            (die.key_tuple(), count)
435            for die, count in self._dice.items()), self._post_roll_counts
436
437    def __eq__(self, other) -> bool:
438        if not isinstance(other, Pool):
439            return False
440        return self._key_tuple == other._key_tuple
441
442    @cached_property
443    def _hash(self) -> int:

def set_post_roll_counts(self, post_roll_counts: int | slice | tuple[int, ...]) 
156    def set_post_roll_counts(self,
157                             post_roll_counts: int | slice | tuple[int, ...]):
158        """Returns a pool with the selected dice counted.
159
160        You can use `pool[post_roll_counts]` for the same effect as this method.
161
162        The dice are sorted in ascending order for this purpose,
163        regardless of which order the outcomes are evaluated in.
164
165        This is always an absolute selection on all `num_dice`,
166        not a relative selection on already-selected dice,
167        which would be ambiguous in the presence of multiple or negative counts.
168
169        For example, here are some ways of selecting the two highest dice out of 5:
170
171        * `pool[3:5]`
172        * `pool[3:]`
173        * `pool[-2:]`
174        * `pool[..., 1, 1]`
175
176        These will also select the two highest dice out of 5, and will also
177        resize the pool to 5 dice first:
178
179        * `pool[3::5]`
180        * `pool[3:5:5]`
181        * `pool[-2::5]`
182        * `pool[0, 0, 0, 1, 1]`
183
184        These will count the highest as a positive and the lowest as a negative:
185
186        * `pool[-1, 0, 0, 0, 1]`
187        * `pool[-1, ..., 1]`
188
189        Args:
190            An `int`. This will count only the die at the specified index (once).
191                In this case, the result will be a `Die`, not a pool.
192            A `slice`. The selected dice are counted once each.
193                If provided, the third argument resizes the pool,
194                rather than being a step; however, this is only valid if the
195                pool consists of a single type of die.
196            A sequence of one `int` for each die.
197                Each die is counted that many times, which could be multiple or
198                negative times. This may resize the pool, but only if the
199                pool consists of a single type of die.
200
201                Up to one `Ellipsis` (`...`) may be used.
202                If an `Ellipsis` is used, the size of the pool won't change.
203                Instead, the `Ellipsis` will be replaced with a number of zero
204                counts, sufficient to maintain the current size of this pool.
205                This number may be "negative" if more `int`s are provided than
206                the size of the pool. Specifically:
207
208                * If `post_roll_counts` is shorter than `num_dice`, the `Ellipsis`
209                    acts as enough zero counts to make up the difference.
210                    E.g. `pool[1, ..., 1]` on five dice would act as `pool[1, 0, 0, 0, 1]`.
211                * If `post_roll_counts` has length equal to `num_dice`, the `Ellipsis` has no effect.
212                    E.g. `pool[1, ..., 1]` on two dice would act as `pool[1, 1]`.
213                * If `post_roll_counts` is longer than `num_dice` and the `Ellipsis` is on one side,
214                    elements will be dropped from `post_roll_counts` on the side with the `Ellipsis`.
215                    E.g. `pool[..., 1, 2, 3]` on two dice would act as `pool[2, 3]`.
216                * If `post_roll_counts` is longer than `num_dice` and the `Ellipsis`
217                    is in the middle, the counts will be as the sum of two
218                    one-sided `Ellipsis`.
219                    E.g. `pool[-1, ..., 1]` acts like `[-1, ...]` plus `[..., 1]`.
220                    On a pool consisting of a single single die this would have
221                    the -1 and 1 cancel each other out.
222
223        Raises:
224            ValueError:  If `post_roll_counts` would change the size of a pool with
225                more than one type of die, or if more than one `Ellipsis`
226                is used.
227        """
228        convert_to_die = isinstance(post_roll_counts, int)
229        post_roll_counts = post_roll_counts_tuple(self.num_dice(),
230                                                  post_roll_counts)
231        if len(post_roll_counts) != self.num_dice():
232            if len(self._dice) != 1:
233                raise ValueError(
234                    'Cannot change the size of a pool unless it has exactly one type of die.'
235                )
236            dice = Counts([(self._dice.keys()[0], len(post_roll_counts))])
237            result = Pool._new_pool(dice, post_roll_counts)
238        else:
239            result = Pool._new_pool(self._dice, post_roll_counts)
240        if convert_to_die:
241            return result.eval(lambda state, outcome, count: outcome
242                               if count else state)
243        else:
244            return result

Returns a pool with the selected dice counted.

You can use pool[post_roll_counts] for the same effect as this method.

The dice are sorted in ascending order for this purpose, regardless of which order the outcomes are evaluated in.

This is always an absolute selection on all num_dice, not a relative selection on already-selected dice, which would be ambiguous in the presence of multiple or negative counts.

For example, here are some ways of selecting the two highest dice out of 5:

  • pool[3:5]
  • pool[3:]
  • pool[-2:]
  • pool[..., 1, 1]

These will also select the two highest dice out of 5, and will also resize the pool to 5 dice first:

  • pool[3::5]
  • pool[3:5:5]
  • pool[-2::5]
  • pool[0, 0, 0, 1, 1]

These will count the highest as a positive and the lowest as a negative:

  • pool[-1, 0, 0, 0, 1]
  • pool[-1, ..., 1]
Args
  • An int. This will count only the die at the specified index (once). In this case, the result will be a Die, not a pool.
  • A slice. The selected dice are counted once each. If provided, the third argument resizes the pool, rather than being a step; however, this is only valid if the pool consists of a single type of die.

  • A sequence of one int for each die. Each die is counted that many times, which could be multiple or negative times. This may resize the pool, but only if the pool consists of a single type of die.

    Up to one Ellipsis (...) may be used. If an Ellipsis is used, the size of the pool won't change. Instead, the Ellipsis will be replaced with a number of zero counts, sufficient to maintain the current size of this pool. This number may be "negative" if more ints are provided than the size of the pool. Specifically:

    • If post_roll_counts is shorter than num_dice, the Ellipsis acts as enough zero counts to make up the difference. E.g. pool[1, ..., 1] on five dice would act as pool[1, 0, 0, 0, 1].
    • If post_roll_counts has length equal to num_dice, the Ellipsis has no effect. E.g. pool[1, ..., 1] on two dice would act as pool[1, 1].
    • If post_roll_counts is longer than num_dice and the Ellipsis is on one side, elements will be dropped from post_roll_counts on the side with the Ellipsis. E.g. pool[..., 1, 2, 3] on two dice would act as pool[2, 3].
    • If post_roll_counts is longer than num_dice and the Ellipsis is in the middle, the counts will be as the sum of two one-sided Ellipsis. E.g. pool[-1, ..., 1] acts like [-1, ...] plus [..., 1]. On a pool consisting of a single single die this would have the -1 and 1 cancel each other out.
Raises
  • ValueError: If post_roll_counts would change the size of a pool with more than one type of die, or if more than one Ellipsis is used.

class OutcomeCountEval(abc.ABC): 
 20class OutcomeCountEval(ABC):
 21    """An abstract, immutable, callable class for evaulating one or more `OutcomeCountGens`s.
 22
 23    There is one abstract method to implement: `next_state()`.
 24    This should incrementally calculate the result given one outcome at a time
 25    along with how many of that outcome were produced.
 26    An example sequence of calls, as far as `next_state()` is concerned, is:
 27
 28    1. `state = next_state(state=None, outcome=1, count=how_many_1s)`
 29    2. `state = next_state(state, 2, how_many_2s)`
 30    3. `state = next_state(state, 3, how_many_3s)`
 31    4. `state = next_state(state, 4, how_many_4s)`
 32    5. `state = next_state(state, 5, how_many_5s)`
 33    6. `state = next_state(state, 6, how_many_6s)`
 34    7. `outcome = final_outcome(state, *gens)`
 35
 36    A few other methods can optionally be overridden to further customize behavior.
 37
 38    It is not expected that subclasses of `OutcomeCountEval`
 39    be able to handle arbitrary types or numbers of gens.
 40    Indeed, most are expected to handle only a fixed number of gens,
 41    and often even only gens with a particular type of die.
 42
 43    Instances cache all intermediate state distributions.
 44    You should therefore reuse instances when possible.
 45
 46    Instances should not be modified after construction
 47    in any way that affects the return values of these methods.
 48    Otherwise, values in the cache may be incorrect.
 49    """
 50
 51    @abstractmethod
 52    def next_state(self, state: Hashable, outcome, /, *counts: int) -> Hashable:
 53        """State transition function.
 54
 55        This should produce a state given the previous state, an outcome,
 56        and the number that outcome produced by each gen.
 57
 58        Within `eval()`, this will be called using only positional arguments.
 59        Thus, you may rename any of the arguments if you wish.
 60
 61        Make sure to handle the base case where `state is None`.
 62
 63        Args:
 64            state: A hashable object indicating the state before rolling the
 65                current outcome. If there was no previous outcome, this will be
 66                `None`.
 67            outcome: The current outcome.
 68                `next_state` will see all rolled outcomes in monotonic order;
 69                either ascending or descending depending on `direction()`.
 70                If there are multiple gens, the set of outcomes is the
 71                union of the outcomes of the invididual gens. All outcomes
 72                with nonzero  count will be visited. Outcomes with zero count
 73                may or may not be visited. If you need to enforce that certain
 74                outcomes are visited even if they have zero count, see
 75                `alignment()`.
 76            *counts: One `int` for each gen indicating how many of the current
 77                outcome were produced. If there are multiple
 78                gens, it's possible that some outcomes will not appear in
 79                all gens. In this case, the count for the gen(s)
 80                that do not have the outcome will be 0. Zero-weight outcomes
 81                count as having that outcome.
 82
 83                Most subclasses will expect a fixed number of gens and
 84                can replace this variadic parameter with a fixed number of named
 85                parameters.
 86
 87        Returns:
 88            A hashable object indicating the next state.
 89            The special value `icepool.Reroll` can be used to immediately remove
 90            the state from consideration, effectively performing a full reroll.
 91        """
 92
 93    def final_outcome(self, final_state: Hashable, /,
 94                      *gens: icepool.OutcomeCountGen) -> Any:
 95        """Optional function to generate a final outcome from a final state.
 96
 97        Within `eval()`, this will be called using only positional arguments.
 98        Thus, you may rename any of the arguments if you wish.
 99
100        By default, the final outcome is equal to the final state.
101        Note that `None` is not a valid outcome for a die,
102        and if there are no outcomes, the final state will be `None`.
103        Subclasses that want to handle this case should explicitly define what
104        happens.
105
106        Args:
107            final_state: A state after all outcomes have been processed.
108            *gens: One or more `OutcomeCountGen`s being evaluated.
109                Most subclasses will expect a fixed number of generators and
110                can replace this variadic parameter with a fixed number of named
111                parameters.
112
113        Returns:
114            A final outcome that will be used as part of constructing the result die.
115            As usual for `Die()`, this could itself be a die or `icepool.Reroll`.
116        """
117        return final_state
118
119    def direction(self, *gens: icepool.OutcomeCountGen) -> int:
120        """Optional function to determine the direction in which `next_state()` will see outcomes.
121
122        The default is ascending order. This works well with mixed standard dice,
123        and other dice that differ only by right-truncation.
124
125        Args:
126            *gens: One or more `OutcomeCountGen`s being evaluated.
127                Most subclasses will expect a fixed number of generators and
128                can replace this variadic parameter with a fixed number of named
129                parameters.
130
131        Returns:
132            * > 0 if `next_state()` should always see the outcomes in ascending order.
133            * < 0 if `next_state()` should always see the outcomes in descending order.
134            * 0 if the order may be determined automatically.
135        """
136        return 1
137
138    def alignment(self, *gens: icepool.OutcomeCountGen) -> Collection:
139        """Optional function to specify an iterable of outcomes that should always be given to `next_state()` even if they have zero count.
140
141        The default implementation returns `()`; this means outcomes with zero
142        count may or may not be seen by `next_state`.
143
144        If you want the outcomes seen by `next_state` to be consecutive
145        `int`s, you can set `alignment = icepool.OutcomeCountEval.range_alignment`.
146        See `range_alignment()` below.
147
148        Returns:
149            An iterable of outcomes that should be given to `next_state()` even
150            if they have zero count.
151        """
152        return ()
153
154    def range_alignment(self,
155                        *gens: icepool.OutcomeCountGen) -> Collection[int]:
156        """Example implementation of `alignment()` that produces consecutive `int` outcomes.
157
158        Set `alignment = icepool.OutcomeCountEval.range_alignment` to use this.
159
160        Returns:
161            All `int`s from the min outcome to the max outcome among the generators,
162            inclusive.
163
164        Raises:
165            `TypeError` if any generator has any non-`int` outcome.
166        """
167        if len(gens) == 0:
168            return ()
169
170        if any(
171                any(not isinstance(x, int)
172                    for x in gen.outcomes())
173                for gen in gens):
174            raise TypeError(
175                "range_alignment cannot be used with outcomes of type other than 'int'."
176            )
177
178        min_outcome = min(gen.min_outcome() for gen in gens)
179        max_outcome = max(gen.max_outcome() for gen in gens)
180        return range(min_outcome, max_outcome + 1)
181
182    @cached_property
183    def _cache(self) -> MutableMapping[Any, Mapping[Any, int]]:
184        """A cache of (direction, gens) -> weight distribution over states. """
185        return {}
186
187    def eval(
188        self, *gens: icepool.OutcomeCountGen | Mapping[Any, int] | Sequence
189    ) -> 'icepool.Die':
190        """Evaluates generators.
191
192        You can call the `OutcomeCountEval` object directly for the same effect,
193        e.g. `sum_gen(gen)` is an alias for `sum_gen.eval(gen)`.
194
195        Args:
196            *gens: Each element may be one of the following:
197                * A `OutcomeCountGen`.
198                * A mappable mapping dice to the number of those dice.
199                * A sequence of arguments to create a `Pool`.
200                Most evaluators will expect a fixed number of gens.
201                The union of the outcomes of the gens must be totally orderable.
202
203        Returns:
204            A `Die` representing the distribution of the final score.
205        """
206
207        # Convert non-pool arguments to `Pool`.
208        converted_gens = tuple(gen if isinstance(gen, icepool.OutcomeCountGen
209                                                ) else icepool.Pool(gen)
210                               for gen in gens)
211
212        if not all(gen._is_resolvable() for gen in converted_gens):
213            return icepool.Die([])
214
215        algorithm, direction = self._select_algorithm(*converted_gens)
216
217        # We use a separate class to guarantee all outcomes are visited.
218        alignment = Alignment(self.alignment(*converted_gens))
219
220        dist = algorithm(direction, alignment, tuple(converted_gens))
221
222        final_outcomes = []
223        final_weights = []
224        for state, weight in dist.items():
225            outcome = self.final_outcome(state, *converted_gens)
226            if outcome is None:
227                raise TypeError(
228                    "None is not a valid final outcome. "
229                    "This may have resulted from supplying an empty gen to OutcomeCountEval. "
230                    "If so, refrain from using empty gens, or override OutcomeCountEval.final_outcome() to handle this case."
231                )
232            if outcome is not icepool.Reroll:
233                final_outcomes.append(outcome)
234                final_weights.append(weight)
235
236        return icepool.Die(final_outcomes, final_weights)
237
238    __call__ = eval
239
240    def _select_algorithm(
241            self, *gens: icepool.OutcomeCountGen) -> tuple[Callable, int]:
242        """Selects an algorithm and iteration direction.
243
244        Returns:
245            * The algorithm to use (`_eval_internal*`).
246            * The direction in which `next_state()` sees outcomes.
247                1 for ascending and -1 for descending.
248
249        """
250        eval_direction = self.direction(*gens)
251
252        pop_min_costs, pop_max_costs = zip(
253            *(gen._estimate_direction_costs() for gen in gens))
254
255        pop_min_cost = math.prod(pop_min_costs)
256        pop_max_cost = math.prod(pop_max_costs)
257
258        # No preferred direction case: go directly with cost.
259        if eval_direction == 0:
260            if pop_max_cost <= pop_min_cost:
261                return self._eval_internal, 1
262            else:
263                return self._eval_internal, -1
264
265        # Preferred direction case.
266        # Go with the preferred direction unless there is a "significant"
267        # cost factor.
268
269        if PREFERRED_DIRECTION_COST_FACTOR * pop_max_cost < pop_min_cost:
270            cost_direction = 1
271        elif PREFERRED_DIRECTION_COST_FACTOR * pop_min_cost < pop_max_cost:
272            cost_direction = -1
273        else:
274            cost_direction = 0
275
276        if cost_direction == 0 or eval_direction == cost_direction:
277            # Use the preferred algorithm.
278            return self._eval_internal, eval_direction
279        else:
280            # Use the less-preferred algorithm.
281            return self._eval_internal_iterative, eval_direction
282
283    def _eval_internal(
284            self, direction: int, alignment: Alignment,
285            gens: tuple[icepool.OutcomeCountGen, ...]) -> Mapping[Any, int]:
286        """Internal algorithm for iterating in the more-preferred direction,
287        i.e. giving outcomes to `next_state()` from wide to narrow.
288
289        All intermediate return values are cached in the instance.
290
291        Arguments:
292            direction: The direction in which to send outcomes to `next_state()`.
293            alignment: As `alignment()`. Elements will be popped off this
294                during recursion.
295            gens: One or more `OutcomeCountGens`s to evaluate. Elements
296                will be popped off this during recursion.
297
298        Returns:
299            A dict `{ state : weight }` describing the probability distribution
300                over states.
301        """
302        cache_key = (direction, alignment, gens)
303        if cache_key in self._cache:
304            return self._cache[cache_key]
305
306        result: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
307
308        if all(not gen.outcomes() for gen in gens) and not alignment.outcomes():
309            result = {None: 1}
310        else:
311            outcome, prev_alignment, iterators = _pop_gens(
312                direction, alignment, gens)
313            for p in itertools.product(*iterators):
314                prev_gens, counts, weights = zip(*p)
315                prod_weight = math.prod(weights)
316                prev = self._eval_internal(direction, prev_alignment, prev_gens)
317                for prev_state, prev_weight in prev.items():
318                    state = self.next_state(prev_state, outcome, *counts)
319                    if state is not icepool.Reroll:
320                        result[state] += prev_weight * prod_weight
321
322        self._cache[cache_key] = result
323        return result
324
325    def _eval_internal_iterative(
326            self, direction: int, alignment: Alignment,
327            gens: tuple[icepool.OutcomeCountGen, ...]) -> Mapping[Any, int]:
328        """Internal algorithm for iterating in the less-preferred direction,
329        i.e. giving outcomes to `next_state()` from narrow to wide.
330
331        This algorithm does not perform persistent memoization.
332        """
333        if all(not gen.outcomes() for gen in gens) and not alignment.outcomes():
334            return {None: 1}
335        dist: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
336        dist[None, alignment, gens] = 1
337        final_dist: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
338        while dist:
339            next_dist: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
340            for (prev_state, prev_alignment, prev_gens), weight in dist.items():
341                # The direction flip here is the only purpose of this algorithm.
342                outcome, alignment, iterators = _pop_gens(
343                    -direction, prev_alignment, prev_gens)
344                for p in itertools.product(*iterators):
345                    gens, counts, weights = zip(*p)
346                    prod_weight = math.prod(weights)
347                    state = self.next_state(prev_state, outcome, *counts)
348                    if state is not icepool.Reroll:
349                        if all(not gen.outcomes() for gen in gens):
350                            final_dist[state] += weight * prod_weight
351                        else:
352                            next_dist[state, alignment,
353                                      gens] += weight * prod_weight
354            dist = next_dist
355        return final_dist

An abstract, immutable, callable class for evaulating one or more OutcomeCountGenss.

There is one abstract method to implement: next_state(). This should incrementally calculate the result given one outcome at a time along with how many of that outcome were produced. An example sequence of calls, as far as next_state() is concerned, is:

  1. state = next_state(state=None, outcome=1, count=how_many_1s)
  2. state = next_state(state, 2, how_many_2s)
  3. state = next_state(state, 3, how_many_3s)
  4. state = next_state(state, 4, how_many_4s)
  5. state = next_state(state, 5, how_many_5s)
  6. state = next_state(state, 6, how_many_6s)
  7. outcome = final_outcome(state, *gens)

A few other methods can optionally be overridden to further customize behavior.

It is not expected that subclasses of OutcomeCountEval be able to handle arbitrary types or numbers of gens. Indeed, most are expected to handle only a fixed number of gens, and often even only gens with a particular type of die.

Instances cache all intermediate state distributions. You should therefore reuse instances when possible.

Instances should not be modified after construction in any way that affects the return values of these methods. Otherwise, values in the cache may be incorrect.

@abstractmethod
def next_state(self, state: Hashable, outcome, /, *counts: int) -> Hashable: 
51    @abstractmethod
52    def next_state(self, state: Hashable, outcome, /, *counts: int) -> Hashable:
53        """State transition function.
54
55        This should produce a state given the previous state, an outcome,
56        and the number that outcome produced by each gen.
57
58        Within `eval()`, this will be called using only positional arguments.
59        Thus, you may rename any of the arguments if you wish.
60
61        Make sure to handle the base case where `state is None`.
62
63        Args:
64            state: A hashable object indicating the state before rolling the
65                current outcome. If there was no previous outcome, this will be
66                `None`.
67            outcome: The current outcome.
68                `next_state` will see all rolled outcomes in monotonic order;
69                either ascending or descending depending on `direction()`.
70                If there are multiple gens, the set of outcomes is the
71                union of the outcomes of the invididual gens. All outcomes
72                with nonzero  count will be visited. Outcomes with zero count
73                may or may not be visited. If you need to enforce that certain
74                outcomes are visited even if they have zero count, see
75                `alignment()`.
76            *counts: One `int` for each gen indicating how many of the current
77                outcome were produced. If there are multiple
78                gens, it's possible that some outcomes will not appear in
79                all gens. In this case, the count for the gen(s)
80                that do not have the outcome will be 0. Zero-weight outcomes
81                count as having that outcome.
82
83                Most subclasses will expect a fixed number of gens and
84                can replace this variadic parameter with a fixed number of named
85                parameters.
86
87        Returns:
88            A hashable object indicating the next state.
89            The special value `icepool.Reroll` can be used to immediately remove
90            the state from consideration, effectively performing a full reroll.
91        """

State transition function.

This should produce a state given the previous state, an outcome, and the number that outcome produced by each gen.

Within eval(), this will be called using only positional arguments. Thus, you may rename any of the arguments if you wish.

Make sure to handle the base case where state is None.

Args
  • state: A hashable object indicating the state before rolling the current outcome. If there was no previous outcome, this will be None.
  • outcome: The current outcome. next_state will see all rolled outcomes in monotonic order; either ascending or descending depending on direction(). If there are multiple gens, the set of outcomes is the union of the outcomes of the invididual gens. All outcomes with nonzero count will be visited. Outcomes with zero count may or may not be visited. If you need to enforce that certain outcomes are visited even if they have zero count, see alignment().

  • *counts: One int for each gen indicating how many of the current outcome were produced. If there are multiple gens, it's possible that some outcomes will not appear in all gens. In this case, the count for the gen(s) that do not have the outcome will be 0. Zero-weight outcomes count as having that outcome.

    Most subclasses will expect a fixed number of gens and can replace this variadic parameter with a fixed number of named parameters.

Returns

A hashable object indicating the next state. The special value icepool.Reroll can be used to immediately remove the state from consideration, effectively performing a full reroll.

def alignment( self, *gens: icepool.OutcomeCountGen) -> collections.abc.Collection: 
138    def alignment(self, *gens: icepool.OutcomeCountGen) -> Collection:
139        """Optional function to specify an iterable of outcomes that should always be given to `next_state()` even if they have zero count.

150            if they have zero count.

152        return ()

def range_alignment( self, *gens: icepool.OutcomeCountGen) -> collections.abc.Collection[int]: 
154    def range_alignment(self,
155                        *gens: icepool.OutcomeCountGen) -> Collection[int]:
156        """Example implementation of `alignment()` that produces consecutive `int` outcomes.
157
158        Set `alignment = icepool.OutcomeCountEval.range_alignment` to use this.
159
160        Returns:
161            All `int`s from the min outcome to the max outcome among the generators,
162            inclusive.
163
164        Raises:
165            `TypeError` if any generator has any non-`int` outcome.
166        """
167        if len(gens) == 0:
168            return ()
169
170        if any(
171                any(not isinstance(x, int)
172                    for x in gen.outcomes())
173                for gen in gens):
174            raise TypeError(
175                "range_alignment cannot be used with outcomes of type other than 'int'."
176            )
177
178        min_outcome = min(gen.min_outcome() for gen in gens)
179        max_outcome = max(gen.max_outcome() for gen in gens)
180        return range(min_outcome, max_outcome + 1)

Example implementation of alignment() that produces consecutive int outcomes.

Set alignment = icepool.OutcomeCountEval.range_alignment to use this.

Returns

All ints from the min outcome to the max outcome among the generators, inclusive.

Raises
  • TypeError if any generator has any non-int outcome.
def eval( self, *gens: icepool.OutcomeCountGen | collections.abc.Mapping[typing.Any, int] | collections.abc.Sequence) -> icepool.Die: 
187    def eval(
188        self, *gens: icepool.OutcomeCountGen | Mapping[Any, int] | Sequence
189    ) -> 'icepool.Die':
190        """Evaluates generators.
191
192        You can call the `OutcomeCountEval` object directly for the same effect,
193        e.g. `sum_gen(gen)` is an alias for `sum_gen.eval(gen)`.
194
195        Args:
196            *gens: Each element may be one of the following:
197                * A `OutcomeCountGen`.
198                * A mappable mapping dice to the number of those dice.
199                * A sequence of arguments to create a `Pool`.
200                Most evaluators will expect a fixed number of gens.
201                The union of the outcomes of the gens must be totally orderable.
202
203        Returns:
204            A `Die` representing the distribution of the final score.
205        """
206
207        # Convert non-pool arguments to `Pool`.
208        converted_gens = tuple(gen if isinstance(gen, icepool.OutcomeCountGen
209                                                ) else icepool.Pool(gen)
210                               for gen in gens)
211
212        if not all(gen._is_resolvable() for gen in converted_gens):
213            return icepool.Die([])
214
215        algorithm, direction = self._select_algorithm(*converted_gens)
216
217        # We use a separate class to guarantee all outcomes are visited.
218        alignment = Alignment(self.alignment(*converted_gens))
219
220        dist = algorithm(direction, alignment, tuple(converted_gens))
221
222        final_outcomes = []
223        final_weights = []
224        for state, weight in dist.items():
225            outcome = self.final_outcome(state, *converted_gens)
226            if outcome is None:
227                raise TypeError(
228                    "None is not a valid final outcome. "
229                    "This may have resulted from supplying an empty gen to OutcomeCountEval. "
230                    "If so, refrain from using empty gens, or override OutcomeCountEval.final_outcome() to handle this case."
231                )
232            if outcome is not icepool.Reroll:
233                final_outcomes.append(outcome)
234                final_weights.append(weight)
235
236        return icepool.Die(final_outcomes, final_weights)

Evaluates generators.

You can call the OutcomeCountEval object directly for the same effect, e.g. sum_gen(gen) is an alias for sum_gen.eval(gen).

Args
  • *gens: Each element may be one of the following:
    • A OutcomeCountGen.
    • A mappable mapping dice to the number of those dice.
    • A sequence of arguments to create a Pool. Most evaluators will expect a fixed number of gens. The union of the outcomes of the gens must be totally orderable.
Returns

A Die representing the distribution of the final score.

class JointEval(icepool.OutcomeCountEval): 
406class JointEval(OutcomeCountEval):
407    """EXPERIMENTAL: An `OutcomeCountEval` that jointly evaluates subevals on the same roll(s) of a gen.
408
409    It may be more efficient to write the joint evaluation directly; this is
410    provided as a convenience.
411    """
412
413    def __init__(self, *subevals: 'OutcomeCountEval'):
414        self._subevals = subevals
415
416    def next_state(self, state, outcome, *counts: int):
417        """Runs `next_state` for all subevals.
418
419        The state is a tuple of the substates.
420        """
421        if state is None:
422            return tuple(
423                subeval.next_state(None, outcome, *counts)
424                for subeval in self._subevals)
425        else:
426            return tuple(
427                subeval.next_state(substate, outcome, *counts)
428                for subeval, substate in zip(self._subevals, state))
429
430    def final_outcome(self, final_state, *gens: icepool.OutcomeCountGen):
431        """Runs `final_state` for all subevals.
432
433        The final outcome is a tuple of the final suboutcomes.
434        """
435        return tuple(
436            subeval.final_outcome(final_substate, *gens)
437            for subeval, final_substate in zip(self._subevals, final_state))
438
439    def direction(self, *gens: icepool.OutcomeCountGen):
440        """Determines the common direction of the subevals.
441
442        Raises:
443            ValueError: If subevals have conflicting directions, i.e. some are
444                ascending and others are descending.
445        """
446        subdirections = tuple(
447            subeval.direction(*gens) for subeval in self._subevals)
448        ascending = any(x > 0 for x in subdirections)
449        descending = any(x < 0 for x in subdirections)
450        if ascending and descending:
451            raise ValueError('Sub-evals have conflicting directions.')
452        elif ascending:
453            return 1
454        elif descending:
455            return -1
456        else:
457            return 0

EXPERIMENTAL: An OutcomeCountEval that jointly evaluates subevals on the same roll(s) of a gen.

It may be more efficient to write the joint evaluation directly; this is provided as a convenience.
