class Deck(icepool.OutcomeCountGen): 
 16class Deck(OutcomeCountGen):
 17    """EXPERIMENTAL: Represents drawing a hand from a deck.
 18
 19    In other words, this is sampling without replacement.
 20    """
 21
 22    _data: Counts
 23    _hand_size: int
 24
 25    def __new__(cls,
 26                outcomes: Mapping[Any, int] | Sequence,
 27                times: Sequence[int] | int = 1,
 28                *,
 29                hand_size: int):
 30        """Constructor for a deck.
 31
 32        Args:
 33            outcomes: The outcomes of the deck, i.e. the cards. This can be
 34                one of the following:
 35
 36                * A dict mapping outcomes to dups.
 37                * A sequence of outcomes.
 38
 39                Each outcome may be one of the following:
 40
 41                * A deck. The outcomes of the deck will be "flattened" into the
 42                    result; a deck object will never contain a deck as an
 43                    outcome.
 44                * A dict mapping outcomes to dups.
 45                * A tuple of outcomes.
 46                    Any tuple elements that are decks or dicts will expand the
 47                    tuple according to their independent joint distribution.
 48                    Use this carefully since it may create a large number of
 49                    outcomes.
 50                * Anything else will be treated as a scalar.
 51            times: Multiplies the number of times each element of `outcomes`
 52                will be put into the deck.
 53                `times` can either be a sequence of the same length as
 54                `outcomes` or a single `int` to apply to all elements of
 55                `outcomes`.
 56        """
 57        if isinstance(outcomes, Deck):
 58            if times == 1:
 59                return outcomes
 60            else:
 61                outcomes = outcomes._data
 62
 63        outcomes, times = icepool.creation_args.itemize(outcomes, times)
 64
 65        self = super(Deck, cls).__new__(cls)
 66        self._data = icepool.creation_args.expand_args_for_deck(outcomes, times)
 67        self._hand_size = hand_size
 68        if self.hand_size() > self.deck_size():
 69            raise ValueError('hand_size cannot exceed deck_size.')
 70        return self
 71
 72    def outcomes(self) -> Sequence:
 73        return self._data.keys()
 74
 75    def dups(self) -> Sequence[int]:
 76        return self._data.values()
 77
 78    def items(self) -> Sequence[tuple[Any, int]]:
 79        return self._data.items()
 80
 81    @cached_property
 82    def _deck_size(self) -> int:
 83        return sum(self._data.values())
 84
 85    def deck_size(self) -> int:
 86        return self._deck_size
 87
 88    def hand_size(self) -> int:
 89        return self._hand_size
 90
 91    @cached_property
 92    def _denomiator(self) -> int:
 93        return icepool.math.comb(self.deck_size(), self.hand_size())
 94
 95    def denominator(self) -> int:
 96        return self._denomiator
 97
 98    def _is_resolvable(self) -> bool:
 99        return len(self.outcomes()) > 0
100
101    def _pop_min(
102        self, min_outcome
103    ) -> Generator[tuple['OutcomeCountGen', int, int], None, None]:
104        if not self.outcomes() or min_outcome != self.min_outcome():
105            yield self, 0, 1
106            return
107
108        deck_count = self.dups()[0]
109
110        min_count = max(0, deck_count + self.hand_size() - self.deck_size())
111        max_count = min(deck_count, self.hand_size())
112        for count in range(min_count, max_count + 1):
113            popped_draw = Deck(
114                self.outcomes()[1:],
115                self.dups()[1:],
116                hand_size=self.hand_size() - count,
117            )
118            weight = icepool.math.comb(deck_count, count)
119            yield popped_draw, count, weight
120
121    def _pop_max(
122        self, max_outcome
123    ) -> Generator[tuple['OutcomeCountGen', int, int], None, None]:
124        if not self.outcomes() or max_outcome != self.max_outcome():
125            yield self, 0, 1
126            return
127
128        deck_count = self.dups()[-1]
129
130        min_count = max(0, deck_count + self.hand_size() - self.deck_size())
131        max_count = min(deck_count, self.hand_size())
132        for count in range(min_count, max_count + 1):
133            popped_draw = Deck(self.outcomes()[:-1],
134                               self.dups()[:-1],
135                               hand_size=self.hand_size() - count)
136            weight = icepool.math.comb(deck_count, count)
137            yield popped_draw, count, weight
138
139    def _estimate_direction_costs(self) -> tuple[int, int]:
140        result = len(self.outcomes()) * self.hand_size()
141        return result, result
142
143    @cached_property
144    def _key_tuple(self) -> tuple:
145        return (Deck,) + tuple(self.items()) + (self.hand_size(),)
146
147    def __eq__(self, other) -> bool:
148        if not isinstance(other, Deck):
149            return False
150        return self._key_tuple == other._key_tuple
151
152    @cached_property
153    def _hash(self) -> int:
154        return hash(self._key_tuple)
155
156    def __hash__(self) -> int:
157        return self._hash

EXPERIMENTAL: Represents drawing a hand from a deck.

In other words, this is sampling without replacement.

Deck( outcomes: collections.abc.Mapping[typing.Any, int] | collections.abc.Sequence, times: collections.abc.Sequence[int] | int = 1, *, hand_size: int) 
25    def __new__(cls,
26                outcomes: Mapping[Any, int] | Sequence,
27                times: Sequence[int] | int = 1,
28                *,
29                hand_size: int):
30        """Constructor for a deck.
31
32        Args:
33            outcomes: The outcomes of the deck, i.e. the cards. This can be
34                one of the following:
35
36                * A dict mapping outcomes to dups.
37                * A sequence of outcomes.
38
39                Each outcome may be one of the following:
40
41                * A deck. The outcomes of the deck will be "flattened" into the
42                    result; a deck object will never contain a deck as an
43                    outcome.
44                * A dict mapping outcomes to dups.
45                * A tuple of outcomes.
46                    Any tuple elements that are decks or dicts will expand the
47                    tuple according to their independent joint distribution.
48                    Use this carefully since it may create a large number of
49                    outcomes.
50                * Anything else will be treated as a scalar.
51            times: Multiplies the number of times each element of `outcomes`
52                will be put into the deck.
53                `times` can either be a sequence of the same length as
54                `outcomes` or a single `int` to apply to all elements of
55                `outcomes`.
56        """
57        if isinstance(outcomes, Deck):
58            if times == 1:
59                return outcomes
60            else:
61                outcomes = outcomes._data
62
63        outcomes, times = icepool.creation_args.itemize(outcomes, times)
64
65        self = super(Deck, cls).__new__(cls)
66        self._data = icepool.creation_args.expand_args_for_deck(outcomes, times)
67        self._hand_size = hand_size
68        if self.hand_size() > self.deck_size():
69            raise ValueError('hand_size cannot exceed deck_size.')
70        return self

Constructor for a deck.

Args

  • outcomes: The outcomes of the deck, i.e. the cards. This can be one of the following:

    • A dict mapping outcomes to dups.
    • A sequence of outcomes.

    Each outcome may be one of the following:

    • A deck. The outcomes of the deck will be "flattened" into the result; a deck object will never contain a deck as an outcome.
    • A dict mapping outcomes to dups.
    • A tuple of outcomes. Any tuple elements that are decks or dicts will expand the tuple according to their independent joint distribution. Use this carefully since it may create a large number of outcomes.
    • Anything else will be treated as a scalar.
  • times: Multiplies the number of times each element of outcomes will be put into the deck. times can either be a sequence of the same length as outcomes or a single int to apply to all elements of outcomes.
